That description was right, as far as it went, but it did not capture the essence of Mr. Brown's life. If it had, it would have read: "Harold Brown Sr., 61, Did Good."

title: Richard Patrick Critchfield, 63, Writer on Life in Third World
description: Richard Patrick Critchfield, an author and journalist who lived and worked among villagers of the third world to tell their story to Western readers, died on Saturday at George Washington Hospital in Washington. He was 63 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: WCI Steel (WRN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary charge of $ 20,214,000, or 62 cents a share, on loss from early retirement of debt, and a gain of $ 834,000, or 2 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: A Private Study Finds Many Children in Shelters Have Signs of Malnutrition
description: Many homeless children tested by health workers in the New York City shelter system suffered from iron deficiency and other symptoms of malnutrition that could severely affect their long-term health, according to a survey by an advocacy group for the homeless.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a meeting between representatives of the British Government and the Irish Republican Army misstated the site in some copies. It was the Parliament Buildings in Belfast, Northern Ireland, not Stormont Castle nearby.

title: Corrections
description: The $25 and Under column in Weekend on Friday, about the restaurant Old Devil Moon in the East Village, misstated the previous positions of the owners, Steve and Tami Latham. They were managers, not owners, at Exterminator Chili in TriBeCa.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DEBORAH NORVILLE, a former "Today" show co-host, marked her seventh wedding anniversary on Monday by giving birth to a son, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor and dancer BEN VEREEN thinks that having a disability should not be a barrier to participating in theater, music or dance, so he is establishing the Ben Vereen School for Performing Arts in Chicago.

title: Polishing The Image Of Louis Armstrong
description: By the time Louis Armstrong died in 1971, he had profoundly changed the culture of the world he was born into. His affability and his musical excellence, underscored by comic genius, combined to make him one of the first great pop figures of the 20th century. He helped create the balancing act between the fine arts and entertainment that has defined the best products of modern American culture.

title: Hartco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1993.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: It's Not Easy Being Green (Just Ask the Stylist)
description: O.K., maybe there is some controversy about the color of Dennis Rodman's hair. He calls it Christmas green. Others have said it's Kelly or neon green. His hair stylist insists that it's none of those, that it's apple green, and is disappointed because Rodman was eager to run a red stripe down the middle for the holidays.

title: Mourning 'a Real Class Act'; Bomb Victim Recalled as Man in Love With Work and Play
description: The smooth contours of the life of Thomas J. Mosser were hardly the kind that might have foretold a violent death: his Roman Catholic boyhood, his rise in business, his commitment to his alma mater, his apparently happy suburban life.

title: Owners Cool on Arbitration Proposal
description: For months, people in baseball and out speculated that if the players agreed to eliminate salary arbitration, the owners would drop their demand for a salary cap and their labor dispute would be history. The players proved that premise wrong today.

title: Don't Martyr a Killer
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dish Of Spinach, So Spanish
description: THIS all-vegetable meal may not make believers out of the hamburger and fries crowd, but it should make it clear that meat is not necessary for appealing, well-seasoned food. The spinach dish is typical of Spain, but despite the fact that most recipes that use pine nuts call for toasting or sauteing them, pine nuts have more flavor when they are not cooked. So add them at the last minute.

title: Television Gets Closer Look As a Factor in Real Violence
description: In 1960, Dr. Leonard D. Eron, a psychology professor at Yale University, embarked on a study to identify the causes of aggression among children. He was most interested in finding out how the children were treated at home, but, to put the parents at ease, he also asked what he called "Ladies' Home Journal questions" about how much television the children watched.

title: Intel's Image Problem
description: Intel's difficulties with Pentium chips have been magnified by a bold ad campaign to make the company a household name by emphasizing the slogan "Intel Inside." Advertising, page D18.

title: Why Kelley Takes His Fights Elsewhere
description: He is, as he likes to point out, "the only champion New York City has." The Queens-born Flushing Flash, whose motto is "Doin it for the People."

title: A Harsh New Arena
description: As new products go, the problems with the Intel Corporation's Pentium microprocessor are little more than the kind of bugs that computer-chip designers expect with each new generation of technology.

title: Antoine Pinay Is Dead at 102; Aided French Postwar Recovery
description: Antoine Pinay, a French statesman who played a major role in restoring health to France's economy after the ravages of World War II, died yesterday at his home in St.-Chamond in central France. He was 102.

title: Jose Leaves the Royals
description: Keeping FELIX JOSE was apparently going to cost too much, so the Kansas City Royals decided to let him go.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The DUCHESS OF YORK, visiting Portugal to help support an AIDS philanthropy, announced yesterday that she had had two AIDS tests, The Press Association, the British news agency, reported. One test was before her first pregnancy in 1988 and the second was for a life insurance policy a year ago.

title: No Headline
description: "I have a tremendous problem understanding what all the hype is about. It's making another set of excuses for kids who are uncontrollably violent. If you're telling me some people can't tell the difference between television and reality, that may be true, but this is someone who's in need of more than censorship." PETER REINHARZ, chief prosecutor for Family Courts in New York City. [ D20:5. ]

title: Not to Forget The Wine
description: Finding the right wines for a meal this rich can be tricky.

title: Surprising the Fashion World, to the Last
description: By all appearances, this was a great year for Alix Gres, the French fashion designer. There was a retrospective of her work held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute in September, attended by Yuzo Yagi, the chairman of Yagi Tsusho Ltd., the Japanese company that had bought the rights to her name in 1988 and had sponsored the exhibition. In Japan, the company was promoting her name anew.

title: In America; Reading, Writing, Reloading
description: Lee Iacocca once said that if you are manufacturing 50,000 cars a week you had better make sure you are selling 50,000 cars a week or you will soon be up to your hindquarters in cars.

title: Aris Industries(AISI,NNM) reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 29
description: b-Included extraordinary gain of $ 26,474,000, or $ 3.04 a share, on debt forgiveness.Revenue represented net revenues.

title: Witnesses Questioned By L.I.R.R. Defendant
description: Acting as his own attorney, Colin Ferguson cross-examined his first witnesses today at a pretrial hearing on charges that he killed six people on the Long Island Rail Road a year ago.

title: Daly Returns in January
description: JOHN DALY, on the sidelines since a scuffle with the father of another player last August, will return to the PGA Tour in the 1995 season-opening Mercedes Championship, Jan. 5-8, in California.

title: Pataki Team Weighs Curb On Welfare
description: Governor-elect George E. Pataki's transition team is reviewing a proposal by a Republican lawmaker that would allow the state to establish sharp new restrictions on welfare benefits to adults deemed able to work.

title: Eating Well; If It Clucks Like A Bowling Ball . . .
description: WHEN people buy chicken at the supermarket, they have every reason to assume it is fresh. It doesn't feel or look frozen.

title: On the Avenue
description: On the day of this season's first, tentative snowfall, Central Park was the sad grays and browns of a Bruegel winter landscape. At Grand Army Plaza the goddess Pomona, bent naked over her bowl, looked colder than ever. Even the ornament over 57th and Fifth seemed to shiver in the chill, damp breeze. The sky did not so much promise as threaten more precipitation.

title: Luby's Cafeterias (LUB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,563,000, or 6 cents a share, from the company's adoption of FASB No. 109 for income taxes. Before the gain, the company earned $ 8,605,000, or 32 cents a share.

title: D'Amato Bows to Prosecutor, Delaying Whitewater Hearing
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who will be chairman of the Senate Banking Committee in the new Congress, said today that Whitewater hearings planned for early next year would be delayed to avoid interfering with the inquiry of the independent counsel for the Whitewater case.

title: Push Is On for Family Doctors To Spot Psychiatric Problems
description: WHILE as many as one in five of the patients who see an internist or family physician may suffer from a psychiatric disorder, the doctors fail to diagnose or treat these problems in as many as 75 percent of cases, according to a report today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: RUSSIAN TROOPS SURROUND REBELS
description: Fighting intensified today in a secessionist Muslim region of southern Russia as Russian troops moved to surround and seal off the region's capital.

title: Give C-Span Greater Reach
description: Few devices have done more to familiarize Americans with the workings of Congress than C-Span. The public affairs cable service, now entering its 16th year, provides gavel-to-gavel coverage of House and Senate sessions and committee hearings, as well as many other government and political events. This unvarnished view, free of editing and commentary, has not always flattered government. It has also given rise to a new breed of couch potato: the C-Span junkie.

title: NATIONAL GYPSUM STOCK RISES ON BUYOUT REPORTS
description: Shares of the National Gypsum Company rose yesterday, as the company's largest shareholder, Delcor Inc., continued to look for a way to buy the company. Delcor, a closely held company controlled by the chairman of National Gypsum, C. D. Spangler Jr., was told on Monday that National Gypsum had rejected its surprise offer of $43.50 a share, made last month. National Gypsum, the nation's second-largest maker of wallboard, said the offer, which valued the company at $940 million, was too low. Delcor said it was continuing to investigate the possibility of acquiring the company. Shares of National Gypsum, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., rose $2.375, to $42.25, in Nasdaq trading. Delcor owns 19 percent of National Gypsum.

title: Battle Returns to the Recital Stage
description: Given all the curious things that have recently happened to Kathleen Battle, it should come as no surprise that the soprano's recital on Monday night at Carnegie Hall was an unconventional one. Yet the sheer oddity of the whole affair left one in a kind of daze. There was the shouting match that broke out in the balconies immediately after the concert began; there was the perplexing presence of Ursula Oppens, the formidable new-music specialist, as accompanist; there was the fluctuating quality of the soprano's own voice, alternately beautiful and bland. Whatever it was, it wasn't dull.

title: A Woman Within a Wild Child, As Revealed by Jodie Foster
description: How fitting that Jodie Foster, in "Nell," should play a free-spirited woman who dances to her own secret music. Ms. Foster has carved out just that role for herself in Hollywood, choosing unusual material and largely avoiding the mainstream. Her independence has been impressive enough to suggest that "Nell," the first film from Ms. Foster's production company, Egg, would be subtler and riskier than ordinary fare.

title: Trak Auto Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a $ 1.3 million after-tax closed store reserve in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Brown and Walters Give Unexpected Spark
description: They both show up early and stay late. When their shots fail and their minutes dwindle, they blame themselves. Affable, articulate, their biggest complaint usually has to do with the windchill factor.

title: Starks Has Film Class He Simply Can't Cut
description: A day after another dismal performance, the Knicks faced some harsh realities.

title: GIULIANI PRESSES TO OUST CORTINES AS SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani intensified his campaign yesterday to push the Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, to resign, saying that he had no confidence in the Chancellor's ability to bring change to the New York City school system.

title: Vicorp Restaurants (VRES,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Included a $ 23 million pretax charge for asset dispositions and restructuring costs in the quarter and year.c-Net income(Loss)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALTEX PETROLEUM CORP., Dallas, a unit of Chevron Corp. and Texaco Inc., opened new offices in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City to promote its products and develop and evaluate investment projects in Vietnam. CUC INTERNATIONAL INC., Stamford, Conn., a membership services company, will acquire Essex Corp., New York, a marketer of financial products for banks, for $27 million in cash and future payments.

title: New doubts about the Pentium chip give Intel a marketing problem with few precedents.
description: WHAT should Intel's marketers do? At stake is an $80 million advertising campaign, begun this fall and culminating this month, that was supposed to make Intel and its Pentium computer chip the gold standard of the computer industry.

title: Reeves Approves Sherrard's Play Book
description: After the Giants' 27-20 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals Sunday, Mike Sherrard called home to California. His mother, who had watched the game on a satellite dish, could not resist needling her fleet son.

title: Small-Scale Bargaining to Tackle the Big Issues
description: Following a week without negotiations, the two sides in the hockey lockout will attempt a different sort of dialogue today. A few members of the bargaining committees will meet at what can be informally described as the subcommittee level, without their leaders present.

title: Eaton Vance Corp.(EAVN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 1.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from a change in accounting for income taxes.Eaton Vance said that its gold operations recorded a profit of 9 cents a share in the latest fourth quarter because of improved gold production levels and stable prices, compared with a loss of 21 cents a share in year-ago period.

title: Market Place; Sony's startling stock comeback draws only mixed reviews.
description: IT was no surprise when the stock of the Sony Corporation plummeted after the company suddenly announced on Nov. 17 that it would suffer a stunning $3.2 billion loss because of problems at its Hollywood studios. What is surprising is how rapidly the stock has recovered.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Enron Corp., Houston, is selling $150 million of notes due in 1996 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The notes are noncallable, carry an interest rate of 8.10 percent and are priced at par to yield 51 basis points more than the two-year Treasury note. The notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service, BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp. and BBB+ by Duff & Phelps Corp.

title: Peacekeeper Dies and U.N. Blames Serbs
description: The Security Council expressed outrage tonight at the death this morning of a Bangladeshi peacekeeper who was forced to endure a nine-hour overland ride to an American field hospital in Zagreb, Croatia, after Serbian troops blocked his medical evacuation by helicopter.

title: CANADA REJECTS CP RAIL BID FOR PART OF CN OPERATIONS
description: The Canadian Government has rejected a $1 billion offer from the CP Rail system to buy the eastern rail network of CN North America. Transport Minister Doug Young made the announcement yesterday in the House of Commons, saying the Government-owned railroad was not "prepared to privatize all rail operations in eastern Canada on the basis of an unsolicited proposal." Mr. Young also said he would announce a new rail policy next year. CP Rail made the takeover offer this summer after talks on a possible freight-line partnership east of Winnipeg, Manitoba, fell apart. During the last five years, CP and CN have had combined losses of $2 billion on their eastern operations.

title: Toll Brothers Inc.(TOL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 668,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and year. The year was also after a gain of $ 1,307,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Toll Brothers said that in fiscal 1994 the value of new sales contracts signed totaled $ 586,941,000 (1,716 homes). The value of the company's backlog of homes under contract at Oct. 31, reached $ 370,560,000 (1,025 homes).In the latest quarter the company signed $ 167,399,000 of new sales contracts (472 homes), compared with $ 145,723,000 (458 homes) in year-ago period.Toll Brothers said although it remains concerned with the general trends in the homebuilding industry, its ''record backlog and our ongoing expansion, we are looking with cautious optimism to a successful 1995.''

title: French Variations on a Holiday Theme
description: AFTER traveling through France for much of the last two years, I have a new appreciation for the younger generation of chefs there who are nudging French cuisine forward while at the same time respecting its time-honored traditions. Thinking about my Christmas menu this year, I decided to incorporate some of the exceptional dishes sampled during those delectable peregrinations.

title: Schoolyard Bully
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines make a good team for New York City. Mr. Giuliani's demand for budget reform has saved millions. Mr. Cortines has gotten the schools focused on teaching. Unfortunately, the two men get along so badly that the Mayor seems intent on making Mr. Cortines miserable enough to quit. The Chancellor says he will decide about that next week.

title: Surgeon General Fought Hard for Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: Lobbyists Will Rush to Fill House Caucus Void
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Sign Gross
description: The Texas Rangers began spending the money they freed in the JOSE CANSECO trade with Boston by signing pitcher KEVIN GROSS and infielder-outfielder MARK MCLEMORE to two-year contracts yesterday.

title: Britain Cool to French Plan To Step Up U.N. Bosnia Effort
description: Britain today declined to endorse a French plan to strengthen the United Nations peacekeeping effort in Bosnia and Herzegovina, raising doubts about NATO's ability to forge a common position on the Bosnian crisis.

title: Bowne & Co. (BNE,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Bowne & Co. said that the decline from the record levels experienced during the first half of the year reflects the volatile nature of the financial printing market.Sales are net sales.

title: Real Estate
description: THE William Sloane House, a 1,400-room building owned by the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York that sheltered many thousands of travelers until it closed in 1991, was sold yesterday to a developer for more than $4 million. The building was once the Y.M.C.A.'s largest hostel.

title: Executive Changes
description: ANESTA CORP., Salt Lake City, appointed Thomas B. King executive vice president, chief operating officer and director. BANKUNITED FINANCIAL CORP., Coral Gables, Fla., appointed Christopher Phillips chief financial officer.

title: The U.S. and Cuba: Double Fantasy
description: Fidel Castro, conspicuously excluded from last week's Miami meeting of hemispheric leaders, sat down afterward with Times reporters. His mood was expansive, and while he acknowledged that he had no wish to import Western-style democracy, he recognized that the world had changed.

title: For Three Cuban Defectors, Getting Fights Is a Victory
description: Two weeks ago, Diobelys Hurtado gave a courier $1,000 to take to Cuba for his parents. They live in Oriente province in a house with a dirt floor and a roof made of palm leaves.

title: Rabbi Benjamin Morgenstern, 87, Educator
description: Rabbi Benjamin Morgenstern, an Orthodox Jewish religious leader and educator for many years, died on Friday at Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. He was 87 and had retired to Jerusalem from Brooklyn nearly 20 years ago.

title: Blast Flattens Fertilizer Plant, Killing 4
description: An early morning explosion demolished a farm chemical plant near here today, killing four workers, injuring at least 15 and sending a huge cloud of ammonia gas drifting over the snow-covered countryside.

title: Fordham to Make Switch To Atlantic 10 Conference
description: Fordham University's decision to abandon the Patriot League next season and join the Atlantic 10 Conference, a move to be announced at a news conference this morning, is a result of a debate over whether players should receive financial aid based strictly upon their athletic skills, according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: Oregon Coach Honored
description: RICH BROOKS, who led Oregon to its first Rose Bowl berth since 1958, won the Bear Bryant award last night as college football's coach of the year.

title: Flawed Airport Design Is Called Cause of 8 Deaths in Crash
description: The crash of a charter flight at Sikorsky Memorial Airport on a foggy night in April was largely the fault of the pilot, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled today, but the fiery deaths of eight of the nine people aboard were caused by the airport's flawed design.

title: New School Concert
description: New Music Mannes, a contemporary vocal and instrumental group, is to present a free concert at 8 P.M. tomorrow at the New School for Social Research, 66 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village. The concert is to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the New School and will include works by composers affiliated with it, with a special tribute to Henry Cowell, who taught there from the 1930's until his death in 1965. The program has four of his works and music by Copland, Cage, Chavez, Ives, Carter, Thomson, Blitzstein and Bowles. Information: (212) 580-0210.

title: That Charming Spider And the Dear Little Pig
description: THE ANNOTATED CHARLOTTE'S WEB By E. B. White Introduction and notes by Peter F. Neumeyer Illustrated. 282 pages. HarperCollins. $35.

title: Simpson Lawyers Ask to Forgo DNA Hearing
description: Lawyers for O. J. Simpson today asked Judge Lance A. Ito to cancel a hearing on the admissibility of DNA evidence and consolidate it instead into Mr. Simpson's trial. But it was unclear whether the prosecution would agree to the defense motion, which could allow testimony to begin shortly after New Year's Day.

title: Ford Is Recovering
description: Boston Celtics Coach CHRIS FORD is expected to make a full recovery after undergoing surgery yesterday to remove an apparently benign polyp on his colon and is expected to resume his duties in about three weeks. Assistant Coach DON CASEY will handle the team in the interim. (AP)

title: Giuliani to Delay Selling Radio Stations
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he plans to sell the city-owned television station, WYNC, Channel 31, and to delay plans to sell its two radio stations, WNYC-FM and WNYC-AM.

title: Struggling Through Crises at Howard University
description: In past years, Howard University has been known as a cradle of black intellectual and cultural life; the place where L. Douglas Wilder learned law, Toni Morrison perfected her prose and Jessye Norman nurtured her soaring soprano. But if in years past Howard has been remembered most for its glories, this year it may be known more for a host of crises and reams of bad publicity.

title: New Mast for Autissier
description: The passage through the Indian Ocean with a jury-rig ended yesterday for ISABELLE AUTISSIER, the BOC round-the-world sailor who lost her boat's mast on Dec. 2. Autissier arrived at the Kerguelen Islands, a mid-ocean chain on which her French support team has arranged to install another mast. It will be a second-hand cruising spar, all they could find, but Autissier hopes it will get her to Sydney, Australia. She plans to set sail again tomorrow. CHRISTOPHE AUGUIN continues to lead the global race on his 60-foot boat Sceta Calberson.

title: U.S. Report On Inflation Spurs Bonds
description: Treasury bonds surged yesterday as buyers were encouraged by a report on producer prices that showed no evidence of inflation accelerating.

title: Pentium Flaw Creates Confusion for PC Buyers
description: Windows or Mac? Pentium or 486? Now or never? Buying a personal computer has never been simple.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Nov. 28 about the pro bono account of the Inner City Scholarship fund misstated the role of an advertising agency. Korey, Kay & Partners of New York created a campaign for the fund; it has not been assigned the account. The account continues to be handled by an in-house agency of the development office of the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Bank's Head Will Retire Early in 1998
description: J. Carter Bacot, the strong-willed chairman of the Bank of New York Company, said yesterday that he would retire in early 1998 and that the bank's board had approved his choice of Thomas A. Renyi to be his successor.

title: 10-Year-Old Charged With Bias Crime
description: A white 10-year-old boy has been charged with racially harassing and threatening to kill a 9-year-old black classmate at a school bus stop, the police said today.

title: Wine Talk
description: IF you're thinking about giving wine gifts this year, why beat around the bush? Buy wine. It's a safe bet that your wine friends have corkscrews. It's just as safe to assume they don't have enough wine. Here are a few ways you can help them out.

title: Dylan for a New Audience
description: Stay-at-homes can now hear and see the revitalized Bob Dylan, who has been turning heads on the concert circuit for a year. With a band that picks up both the roots and the immediacy in every song, Mr. Dylan savors and reinvestigates lyrics he has been singing for up to three decades. On "MTV Unplugged: Bob Dylan," tonight at 8, "The Times They Are A-Changin'," from 1963, takes on its latest new connotations after the 1994 elections.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing DICK SIMON RACING -- Signed Dean Hall, driver, for the 1995 Indy-car season. Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Acquired Terry Shumpert, infielder, from the Kansas City Royals for a player to be named. Signed Joel Johnston, pitcher, to a minor- league contract.

title: The New Yorker Names A New Fiction Editor
description: The New Yorker has named Bill Buford, the publisher of the British literary magazine Granta, to be its fiction and literary editor. The title is a new one.

title: Orange County to Gradually Sell Fund in Effort to Limit Its Losses
description: Orange County said today that it would sell all the holdings in its investment fund in an effort to minimize further losses, setting off a scramble among local governments and agencies in the fund to recover as much of their money as possible.

title: Holtzbrinck Buys a Majority Of Farrar, Straus & Giroux
description: The German publishing concern Holtzbrinck has bought a majority interest in Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the American book publisher's founder said yesterday.

title: Michigan Suicide Bill Advances
description: The Michigan House of Representatives gave final legislative approval today to a measure that would again outlaw assisted suicide, but then voted to put the ban before the state's voters in November 1996.

title: Add a Huge Hit Movie To a Data Base, and Stir
description: OVER the last 30 years, a cookbook writer's persona has steadily become more important than his or her recipes. Now a persona has "written" a cookbook. "The Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. Cookbook," a collection of recipes and reflections from Forrest Gump, was probably inevitable.

title: Clinton Is Reported Set to Seek Revolution in Mortgage Agency
description: Federal officials said today that President Clinton would probably ask Congress to replace the Federal agency that provides mortgage insurance to millions of home buyers with a new Government-controlled corporation that operates more like a private business.

title: Food Notes
description: 'Sprates' With Purpose . . .

title: Tenneco's Plan May Reap $1 Billion
description: Analysts valued a plan announced yesterday by Tenneco Inc. to sell its chemicals division in a public offering at $900 million to $1 billion, or about $750 million in after-tax proceeds.

title: Wachtler, in Post-Prison Speech, Recalls a Steep Fall From Grace
description: The keynote speaker at tonight's monthly meeting of the Westchester County Bar Association chose as his topic "Changes in the Criminal Justice System." It is a subject that he knows all too intimately.

title: Friedel Dzubas, 79, Abstract Painter Of New York School
description: Friedel Dzubas, an abstract painter associated with the New York School in the 1950's and Color Field art in the 60's, died on Sunday at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 79.

title: Polish Cereal Purchase
description: A joint venture of the food makers Nestle S.A. and General Mills Inc. has purchased a Polish cereal maker, the companies said today. Financial terms were not disclosed. The venture, CPW S.A., purchased Turon-Pacific, Poland's leading maker of corn flakes. Turon-Pacific was privatized in 1990. The purchase includes one factory.

title: Looking for Life, Jets Look at 2 Rookies
description: Yes, the Jets are almost buried for yet another season. They are 6-8, they have lost their last three games and they need an improbable set of circumstances to occur just to qualify for the playoffs. In many respects, their season died during that fourth quarter comeback engineered by Miami's Dan Marino at Giants Stadium three weeks ago.

title: Madison Avenue Businesses Work to Improve Community Life; Judge Not, and Give
description: To the Editor:

title: How Rent, Not Food, Can Hold a Restaurant's Fate
description: LA COTE BASQUE, one of New York City's most esteemed and historic restaurants, has lost its lease after 36 years and will be moving in April. As is true of so many restaurants in New York, its dislocation has little to do with food quality, dining trends or management practices. It will have to move, and take on the risk and disruption that entails, because the Walt Disney Company wants to open a gift shop in the space, at 5 East 55th Street, and has offered the landlord substantially more than the $750,000 a year La Cote Basque pays for its 4,500 square feet.

title: DDB Needham Gets Moulinex Account
description: Moulinex S.A., the maker of household appliances like microwaves and coffee machines in Bagnolet, France, said yesterday that it had selected DDB Needham Worldwide to handle its consolidated account, previously divided among several local agencies. Billings were estimated at $40 million. DDB Needham, which already handles Moulinex brands in markets including Asia, was awarded the account after a review that was narrowed to DDB Needham and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. DDB Needham France in Paris will serve as the lead agency.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Atlantic 10, Here Comes Fordham!
description: The luncheon was over at Madison Square Garden, a new era had begun, and the last van was leaving for the Bronx. Fordham University's marriage with the Atlantic 10 Conference had been announced with the deep public conviction that the Rams were making the right commitment, at the right time, for all the right reasons.

title: Blood-Testing Concerns Plan $1.79 Billion Merger
description: National Health Laboratories and Roche Biomedical Laboratories announced a $1.79 billion merger yesterday that would create the largest blood-testing company in the nation.

title: Ault Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 5.2 million, or 28 cents a share, related to the closure of a plant in Napanee, Ont.Second-quarter net sales for refrigerated and frozen products group was 0.04 percent higher than in the year-earlier period. Six-month net sales were 3.4 prcent ahead of last year, the company said.Second-quarter net sales were 10.7 percent ahead of last year in the cheese and butter products group. The Lovell & Christmas dairy products trading business acquired in April contributed to the sales increase and has performed well.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Personal finance magazines are profiting from concern over financial markets.
description: IT seems most unlikely that 1994 will go down in history as a great year for the financial markets. Stocks, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 index, are down close to 3 percent thus far, while the price of the 30-year Treasury bond has dropped so much that its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, is up nearly one-fourth.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a $ 750,000, third-quarter nonrecurring charge, related to the severance and outplacement costs associated with a previously announced reduction in administrative staff in the quarter and 9 months.The latest quarter also included costs associated with the company's last-in, first-out inventory valuation method which increased over the prior year's third quarter by about $ 1 million. The latest 9 months was also after a charge of $ 389,000, or 7 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net income(Loss)

title: National Guard Jet Crashes Into Apartments, Killing 2
description: A jet approaching the Fresno airport after taking part in military war games crashed into a residential street about two miles away shortly before noon today, destroying an apartment complex and spreading fuel and fire.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: MAYOR SEEKS ROLE IN PICKING CHANCELLOR Mayor Giuliani said that although he did not have the legal power to select a new schools chancellor, he wanted the Board of Education to recognize that it had to work with him to pick a successor to Ramon C. Cortines, whom the Mayor has been pressuring to leave. A1. NEW YORK CITY CARDINAL TO LEAD ST. PATRICK'S PARADE John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, accepted the honorary post of grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade with a nod to his late father, "who would have been excited because he said I'd never amount to anything." B3.

title: As Tours Go, Faldo Prefers PGA to World
description: The question didn't catch Nick Faldo by surprise, but his reply will certainly shake up a few people in the headquarters of the World Golf Tour. Faldo, when asked today what he thought of the upstart tour that is attempting to lure the top 30 players in the the world for a $25 million series that would begin play in 1995, shrugged his shoulders and tartly replied: "What World Tour? It isn't going to happen."

title: People
description: * Jack H. Irving, executive vice president at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, was named to the additional new post of director for media.

title: U.S. Notes And Bills Stage Rally
description: Treasury prices ended mixed yesterday after a report on consumer prices confirmed many investors' expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates this month.

title: On Trial: Turkey's Kurdish Policy
description: A Turkish court has sentenced eight Kurdish members of Parliament to prison for doing what representatives in a democracy are supposed to do -- speaking out in behalf of their constituents. Washington was right to protest this gross injustice. It is a stain on Turkey's human rights record.

title: Ailey Excerpts in a Bow to Jamison
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater loves parties. On Tuesday night at City Center, the company paid tribute to Judith Jamison, the longtime Ailey star who is celebrating her fifth anniversary as artistic director of the company.

title: Clinton Cliffhanger
description: In his speech tonight, Bill Clinton faces the most critical point in a Presidency as stuffed with crises as an old-time movie serial.

title: The Fed's Making War on the Business Cycle; Cost to Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EMERGY WORLDWIDE, Palo Alto, Calif., the global logistics service unit of Consolidated Freightways Inc., bought six Boeing 727 jets from UAL Corp.'s United Airlines. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Comeback Kid's Tightest Corner Yet
description: President Clinton faces the most critical point in a Presidency as stuffed with crises as an old-time movie serial.

title: Measurex Corp.(MX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: b-Included restructuring costs of $ 6,381,000 in the quarter and year. The per-share earnings were not disclosed. The year was also after a gain of $ 524,000, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net income(Loss)

title: A Dream in Harlem Ends at the Gavel
description: FOR years, Aunt Len's Doll and Toy Museum in Harlem was a fixture where schoolchildren and collectors were welcome and ordinary grown-ups had to persevere to gain entry.

title: Faubus Legacy in Arkansas: Millions for Desegregation
description: For Arkansas, the legacy of the 1957 desegregation crisis at Central High School and former Gov. Orval Faubus's role in it is now measured less in terms of the racial trauma it once symbolized and more in terms of the bottom line: $180 million and running.

title: Toronto Journal; A Land Apart: A Canadian Looks South Sourly
description: When American invaders crossed the Niagara frontier during the War of 1812, they came upon the family farm of one of the forebears of the author Robertson Davies and were astonished to find angry youths shooting at them from the farmhouse windows.

title: No Headline
description: "He said, 'Don't worry, nobody move. You guys are getting held hostage.' Stuff you see in movies." -- LISA CRAMER, a member of an Albany university class that was held hostage by a rifle wielding student. [ B1:2. ]

title: NATO and U.N. Call Meeting on Bosnia
description: Top Western generals and United Nations commanders will hold an emergency meeting next week to try to bolster the faltering peacekeeping efforts in Bosnia, Western officials said today.

title: The Last Shall Be First
description: The new Republican majority has pledged that term limits will be a top priority in the next Congress. Yet it seems improbable that career politicians such as Strom Thurmond, a Senator since 1954, will step aside simply because their party has promised Congressional turnover. It also seems unlikely that restrictions on Congressional candidates -- beyond those of age and residency specified by the Constitution -- will pass judicial muster.

title: The Fed's Making War on the Business Cycle; Misplaced Euphoria
description: To the Editor:

title: 6-Day Weeks for Tracks
description: Six-day racing weeks will resume at Belmont next spring and continue for most of the year in meetings at Saratoga and Aqueduct, the New York Racing Association announced yesterday as it fleshed out a 286-day thoroughbred racing calendar for 1995.

title: Investigators Find a Name From Bomb
description: Looking for new leads in their search for a serial bomber who mailed the package that killed an advertising executive on Saturday in New Jersey, Federal investigators today released the name on the return address on the envelope.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc.(ROBN,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Kohl Names Abortion Foe To Family Post in Cabinet
description: With German political parties still struggling four years after unification to reach consensus on a new abortion law to replace one that the courts rejected as unconstitutional, Chancellor Helmut Kohl has given the debate a new twist by naming an opponent of abortion as his Cabinet minister in charge of family policy.

title: Calendar: Wreaths And Such
description: Wreaths by Artists Arsenal Gallery, Fifth Avenue at 64th Street in Central Park; (800) 834-3832.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Long Time Between Shows, Long Enough for Obscurity American Symphony Orchestra

title: Five Years And $300 Million -- A special report.; The Maddening Mysteries Of the Greatest Art Theft Ever
description: It was an electrifying tip, the kind of promising break that the F.B.I. had been hoping for since the early hours of March 18, 1990, when a brazen robbery team looted the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum of treasures valued at $300 million.

title: Strawberry Pleads Not Guilty Over Taxes
description: Darryl Strawberry waved to onlookers and smiled for the television cameras this morning as he emerged from the Federal courthouse, where he had pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy and Federal tax evasion.

title: Negotiations Collapse in the Bottom of the Ninth Inning
description: The wisp of hope that flickered at the baseball bargaining table early this morning blew out this afternoon in the ill wind that sent the players home and the owners to Chicago for a decision on impasse and implementation of a salary cap on Thursday.

title: Legal Titans Square Off In Big Tobacco Lawsuit
description: In a much-anticipated court hearing yesterday, prominent negligence lawyers squared off against the tobacco industry, seeking permission from a Federal judge to sue on behalf of the tens of millions of Americans they say are addicted to cigarettes.a

title: Mark IV Industries(IV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 1.1 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and 3 cents a share in the 9 months, on loss from extinguishment of debt.c-Net loss, which was after an extraordinary charge of $ 47.7 million, or $ 1.12 a share, from debt extinguishment and noncash expense from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for postretirement benefits.(Loss)All figures restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend issued in April 1994.Mark IV Industries said sales in the latest quarter were increased 24 percent by one month's results of Purolator Products Co. and positive foreign currency effects.

title: Many Tinkers' Flights of Fancy
description: "AMERICAN artisans turned something ordinary into something extraordinary," Thomas Woodard said. "These truly utilitarian wire objects glow with a life of their own." He was referring to 50 vintage wire objects that he has put on display in his folk art gallery. They range from household items, like cake racks, to a folk art rooster (right) and a bird cage in the form of a cat.

title: Ever Think About the 2.5 Million New Yorkers Who Smoke?
description: To the Editor:

title: Carl Marzani, 82, 'Loyalty' Case Defendant, Dies
description: Carl Marzani, a former employee of the Office of Strategic Services and the State Department imprisoned after being convicted of hiding his Communist Party affiliation from Government loyalty examiners, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Corrections
description: The Pulse chart in The Metro Section on Tuesday, comparing office rents in several cities, included an incorrect figure supplied by Colliers International, a real estate company, for the average cost of office space in Washington. The average annual rent for all of Washington inside the Beltway is $32.43 a square foot, not $48.81; the higher figure is the average for offices in one area of the central business district.

title: From the Street to a Room With a View
description: After midnight, he would wander the sidewalks, collecting empty cans to pay for his breakfast coffee. Toward dawn, he would nap at the 79th Street Boat Basin, then wake for another day of futile job-searching. In Charles Foreste's six years of homelessness, the depression never left him.

title: Clinton Tax Plan Said to Include Family Credits and Student Help
description: The White House is preparing to propose about $50 billion in income tax cuts, probably through a mix of tax credits for families with preschool children and new deductions for college and technical education, Administration aides said today.

title: Time to Act on Cubans and Haitians in Camps
description: To the Editor:

title: Across India, Bitter Fight Is Dividing Ruling Party
description: After a series of four state elections gave it one of the worst drubbings in its history, the governing Congress Party has moved into bitter internal wrangling that has centered on the leadership of the Prime Minister and on the wide-ranging program of market economic reforms he has led since taking office in 1991.

title: Ever Think About the 2.5 Million New Yorkers Who Smoke?; And Then Ban Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Revco D.S. Inc.(RXR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 12
description: b-Included extraordinary charge of $ 2.8 million, or 5 cents a share, on loss from early retirement of debt.Revco D.S. said that earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) increased to $ 47.7 million in the latest fiscal second quarter from $ 24 million in year-ago period. The company also said that EBITDA for the latest six months rose to $ 82.1 million from $ 46.8 million in year-ago period.The company said that earnings for the latest quarter reflected strong sales and profit gains following the recent acquisition of Hook-SupeRx Inc.

title: U.S. Shouldn't Favor Bosnian Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip S. Foner, Labor Historian and Professor, 84
description: Philip S. Foner, an eminent Marxist labor historian who won an apology from City College 40 years after a hunt for Communists cost him his position there, died on Tuesday at Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia after a long illness. He was 84.

title: Jets' 49er-Style Offense Lacks the Substance
description: With only two games left in the season and facing elimination from the playoff derby, the Jets are still trying to get the hang of their offense. The heralded 49ers-type attack that looked promising in the summer has produced a series of dropped balls, stuffed runs and wrong-way routes.

title: A Dreary December for Eagles' Cunningham
description: Randall Cunningham is one of the National Football League's most gifted quarterbacks, perhaps the best scrambling quarterback ever. He is also one of the most puzzling, an articulate 31-year-old man who has exasperated coaches and teammates because he has seldom accepted responsibility when things have gone wrong.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Life on the Internet; Christmas Spirit Misfires As Santa Gets 'Spammed'
description: The bad side of Santa Claus's "naughty and nice" data base just swelled by several megabytes, computer experts said yesterday, after unknown Grinches bombarded his North Pole Internet address with thousands of electronic Christmas letters.

title: METROCALL MAY INCREASE BID FOR USA MOBILE
description: Metrocall Inc. said yesterday that it might increase its bid for USA Mobile Communications Holdings Inc. by valuing the company's stock above the $13 a share it offered earlier this month. Metrocall, based in Alexandria, Va., has offered to buy USA Mobile and Premiere Page Inc. for about $200 million in stock. In a letter to USA Mobile, Christopher A. Kidd, chief executive of Metrocall, said, "We are prepared to consider a valuation for USA Mobile's stock well above the $13 per share of our Dec. 7 merger proposal." Premiere Page and USA Mobile have rejected Metrocall's first proposal, calling the offer inadequate. USA Mobile, based in Cincinnati, is planning a merger with Premiere Page but the companies have postponed a shareholder vote on the issue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture from the Allsport agency in some editions on Dec. 4, with an article about the fight between Riddick Bowe and Larry Donald, was transmitted in error. It showed two other boxers, Greg Harrington and Hasim Rahman.

title: Catherine Shouse Dies at 98; Founded Wolf Trap Arts Park
description: Catherine Filene Shouse, the philanthropist and arts patron who was the founder and major benefactor of the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts in Virginia, died yesterday at her home in Naples, Fla. She was 98 and also had homes in Washington, Easton, Md., and Vienna, Va., where Wolf Trap is situated.

title: Evolution as Spiritual Free-for-All
description: It has always been easy to spot Moses Pendleton's distinctive touch within the creative commune that has called itself Pilobolus for 25 years. While his fellow choreographers there have never been short on imagination, they have rarely matched the unbridled fantasy that identifies Mr. Pendleton's independent work in Momix, the troupe he founded in 1984.

title: Tribune to Buy Shares
description: The Tribune Company said today that it planned to buy back up to five million shares of its stock. The company, which owns The Chicago Tribune, television stations and other media properties, has about 66.7 million common shares outstanding.

title: Countrywide Credit Industries(CCR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: All figures were adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split paid May 3.The latest third quarter included a pretax loss of $ 25.6 million on the sale of loans, compared with a gain of $ 21.8 million in year-ago period.The latest nine months included a pretax loss of $ 30.3 million on the sale of loans, compared with a gain of $ 65.7 million in the same period a year earlier.

title: After Year of Despair, Tobacco Farmers Enjoy Prospect of Better Times
description: This time last year, tobacco country was awash with doomsayers, and John Collett, a tobacco farmer for three decades, felt little but gloom.

title: Orange County's Fatal Error
description: The bankruptcy of Orange County, California -- the biggest municipal bankruptcy ever -- is turning chaotic. The county's investment fund, whose contributors include 60 school districts and 11 water districts, is no longer returning principal or interest to its participants. The cutoff forced the county to suspend highway repairs and tax refunds. Schools, which were legally required to invest in the fund, health clinics and social service providers may run out of money to pay salaries.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Hospitals Use Bodies of Dead For Practice
description: A new survey has found that doctors at many teaching hospitals learn techniques by practicing on people who have just died, but rarely ask permission of the patients' families.

title: Transit Aides Flouting Rule On Residency
description: For 15 years, the Transit Authority has circumvented or ignored a requirement that its managers live in New York City, and as a result more than half of its senior officials reside outside the city, according to an audit released yesterday.

title: Market Place; In a sea of takeovers, a hospital chain defends its independence.
description: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES INC., a small but highly profitable hospital chain, was promoted by analysts as a takeover candidate earlier this year during a flurry of hospital acquisitions. With Columbia-HCA Healthcare, the nation's biggest hospital group, buying Healthtrust, and National Medical Enterprises merging with American Medical Holdings, investors jumped into Universal Health Services.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Autumn Amaryllis

title: Brookstone
description: Shares of Brookstone Inc., a retailer of tools and specialized gadgets, fell to a 52-week low of $7, down $5.75, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Despite a strong holiday season for the industry, Brookstone said fourth-quarter earnings would be below expectations.

title: Panel on a U.S. Benefits Overhaul Fails to Agree on Proposals
description: After 10 months of work, a Federal advisory commission said today that it could not agree on any specific proposals to slow the growth of Social Security, Medicare or other Government benefit programs.

title: Radiation Test Secrecy Linked to Lawsuit Fears
description: Military and nuclear energy officials were motivated by fear of lawsuits and unfavorable publicity in their decision to keep secret many experiments using radiation on humans, Federal investigators have found.

title: GOLDMAN, SACHS WARNS OF NEW ROUND OF LAYOFFS
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company is preparing a second round of layoffs, according to employees at the investment bank. A memo was circulated late Tuesday that called staff reductions "unfortunately inevitable," a Goldman employee said. The memo did not indicate how many employees would be laid off. In October, Goldman, the privately held investment banking firm based in New York, said it was cutting 450 employees from its staff of 9,000, a reduction of 5 percent. Those layoffs mainly involved traders and support staff in the firm's fixed-income securities department. It is unclear what areas of the firm would be affected by the second round of layoffs.

title: Silver Wares, With a Balinese Influence
description: LONG celebrated for his hefty, stylish sterling-silver jewelry, John Hardy has turned to home accessories. Mr. Hardy, who was born in Canada and now lives in Bali, has studied ancient Balinese silver-working techniques, like beading, granulation and silver weaving. He has incorporated these into his designs for hand-hammered sterling salad bowls, teapots and silver-trimmed ice buckets and champagne flutes. A single craftsman makes each piece in its entirety. "Everything has a certain integrity that's very Balinese," Mr. Hardy said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL Camby Paces UMass Marcus Camby scored a season-high 30 points as fifth-ranked Massachusetts, playing the uptempo game it prefers, beat Princeton, 88-67, last night at Amherst, Mass. The 6-foot-11-inch Camby was too much for the defense of the smaller Tigers. And the slowdown tactics that Princeton Coach Pete Carril uses to stay close to more talented teams didn't work against Massachusetts (4-1). Princeton (3-2) was led by Rick Hielscher with 20 points and James Mastaglio with 15. UMass' on-campus winning streak grew to 36 games. (AP) Georgia Tech 86, Georgia 78: In a game matching unbeaten teams, James Forrest of 14th-ranked Georgia Tech scored 8 of his 26 points in a span of 2:14 after visiting Georgia had cut a 23-point deficit to 1 point. Georgia Tech (6-0) had taken advantage of Bulldog turnovers on its way to a 34-11 lead after 11 minutes had elapsed. Shandon Anderson led Georgia (5-1) with 21 points. (AP)

title: Commercial Intertech Corp.(TEC,N) reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5,462,000, or 36 cents a share.

title: Man in the News; Chechen Warrior Chief: Soviet Army Credentials -- Dzhokhar M. Dudayev
description: Dzhokhar M. Dudayev, the flamboyant leader of the breakaway Chechen region, was the first Chechen in the history of the Soviet Union to become a general, commanding a strategic bomber wing at the age of 36.

title: Hero in Hostage Crisis: History Major From L.I.
description: As the police tried to piece together the events surrounding a 2 1/2-hour hostage drama here today, one thing was clear: Jason McEnaney, a history major from Hicksville, L.I., played the dominant role in bringing the standoff to a conclusion.

title: World News Briefs; Iranian Rejects Call To Guide Shiite Muslims
description: Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, today rejected official efforts to promote him as the leading spiritual guide of the world's Shiite Muslims, but he said he still intended to exercise leadership over Shiites outside Iran.

title: British Runner Banned, Will Protest
description: The former Commonwealth 800-meter champion DIANE MODAHL was found to have taken performance-enhancing drugs and was banned for four years by the British Athletic Federation yesterday. In a verdict that stunned the British news media and top-name athletes supporting Modahl, a five-person federation disciplinary panel rejected her case that samples had been improperly handled. Modahl said she will appeal the ruling before an independent arbitration panel to be set up by the federation. (AP)

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDWARD I. KOCH turned 70 on Monday, and on Tuesday, just as they have for the last six years, friends and associates gathered to celebrate.

title: Ennui as Inspiration In the History of Fiction
description: BOREDOM The Literary History of a State of Mind By Patricia Meyer Spacks 290 pages. University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: Consumer Prices Rise Moderately
description: Inflation continued at a moderate pace while a rising tide of goods flowed out of the nation's factories and mines in November, according to Government reports made public today. Together, they provided new evidence of the American economy's robust health.

title: Farewell, National Prune Day
description: The 104th Congress has not yet begun. But the incoming class of 73 new Republican House members can already claim one small victory for common sense. Last week the Republican Conference approved a freshman-sponsored resolution to end the embarrassing Congressional tradition of honoring what is trivial and, thus, of trivializing what is honorable. It is this tradition that has given us empty commemorative events like National Tap Dance Day and Dairy Goat Awareness Week.

title: Schedule Provides No Relief for Knicks
description: Unless the Knicks play better basketball than they have recently, the rest of the week could be a losing proposition.

title: Corrections
description: A notice on the Health page yesterday with an article about prostate cancer support groups omitted the telephone number for one source of information on Us-Too groups, the Prostate Cancer Support Network. It is (800) 828-7866.

title: Gunman Terrorizes Students in Campus Siege
description: Thirty-five students at the State University here showed up this morning for the last day of class in the History of Ancient Greece, expecting the usual fare, bloody but distant: wars, empire, Alexander the Great.

title: 3Com Corp.(COMS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included charges for purchased in-process technology associated with the acquisition of NiceCom Ltd. and a nonrecurring item of $ 1.1 million. Pro forma net income excluding the charges and the nonrecurring items was $ 39.3 million, or 55 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 67.8 million, or 95 cents a share, in the 6 months.c-Included a pretax gain of $ 17,746,000 on sale of investment.Per share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split, effective Sept. 1.

title: Bridge
description: Nearly all those who plan to go to the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, beginning March 31 in Phoenix, face an expensive trip. The lucky minority are those who finished first or second in their district North American Open Pairs Championships at any of three levels, because the national organization will pay for their trip.

title: GOVERNMENT SETS A SAFETY REVIEW AT EVERY AIRLINE
description: As investigators began picking up clues to the cause of the second fatal commuter plane crash in six weeks, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena today ordered a safety audit of the nation's airlines, and an accelerated timetable for new, stricter safety rules for commuter airlines.

title: Leo Burnett Makes Andersen's Roster
description: Arthur Andersen, the worldwide accounting and business-consulting firm, said yesterday that it would formalize its relationship with the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago by adding that agency to its roster. Burnett, which has handled a marketing project for the last nine months, was named as the first agency to handle Andersen's corporate image advertising. Billings were not determined.

title: Scholastic Corp.(SCHL,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 8,135,000, or 50 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Meola Signs With Buffalo Pro Team
description: TONY MEOLA, the goaltender for the United States World Cup team, signed yesterday with the Buffalo Blizzard of the National Professional Soccer League. He was a two-time first-team All-American at Virginia. More recently, he had a tryout with the New York Jets as a place-kicker but failed to make the roster. (AP)

title: U.N. Troops Help Rwanda To Strip Camp Of Weapons
description: In an abrupt departure from its usual role, United Nations forces joined Government troops today to raid a refugee camp in the southwest, seizing weapons and arresting people.

title: How to Keep Tabs On Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Youths Accused of Beating and Shouting Racial Slurs at Brooklyn Couple
description: A black man and a white woman were beaten by a group of black and Hispanic youths who shouted racial slurs during two separate confrontations in Flatbush, Brooklyn, early yesterday, the police said, and the attack was being investigated as a possible bias crime.

title: THEATER
description: Love Among the Hustlers In a Streetwise Triangle 'Trafficking in Broken Hearts' Atlantic Theater Company

title: NOVELL STOCK FALLS ON LOW FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: Shares of Novell Inc. fell 8 percent yesterday after the software company reported lower fourth-quarter earnings late on Tuesday. Some analysts were disappointed by Novell's earnings and said they were concerned about the company's high expenses. Novell's stock fell $1.375, to $15.875, in Nasdaq trading, where its volume of 15.4 million shares was the largest of the day. Novell earned $61 million, or 17 cents a share, in the quarter that ended Oct. 29, down from $88 million, or 24 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Earnings for both periods did not include merger and restructuring expenses.

title: Overtime Stands Still And Dunks The Nets
description: Coach Mike Fratello of the Cavaliers called it "a special play." But Cleveland forward Tyrone Hill claimed there was nothing special about it. "When you have only three-tenths of a second to play, you think up whatever you can that might work," Hill said.

title: Rabbi Benjamin Morgenstern, 87, Educator
description: Rabbi Benjamin Morgenstern, an Orthodox Jewish religious leader and educator for many years, died on Friday at Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. He was 87 and had retired to Jerusalem from Brooklyn nearly 20 years ago.

title: Seeing Jewelry As Fine Art
description: "THESE are no mere baubles -- jewelry is now America's most provocative art form," said Susan Grant Lewin, whose new book, "One of a Kind: American Art Jewelry Today" (Harry N. Abrams, $49.50), profiles 54 jewelry artists. "William Harper, for example, abandoned a career as a painter to do jewelry full time.

title: Where Lies Paradise? In Life Writ Small
description: FOR children, doll houses can make the universe seem obedient. My small cosmos was a converted bookcase, four polished shelves on which I created happier versions of my real-life home.

title: Nike in Accord to Purchase Hockey Equipment Maker
description: Branching out in providing equipment for the feet, Nike Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $395 million for Canstar Sports Inc., a Canadian company that is a leading manufacturer of ice skates and hockey equipment.

title: National Beverage Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Included a loss of $ 455,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and income of $ 159,000, or 3 cents a share, in the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Stewart Enterprises Inc.(STEI,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 4,238,004, or 24 cents a share.

title: Terrence Clancy, 60, a Leader In the California Wine Industry
description: Terrence D. Clancy, a wine industry executive and vice chairman of the Wine Alliance in Healdsburg, Calif., died on Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 60.

title: End of a Nuclear Generation
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority's decision to halt construction of three nuclear plants is the symbolic death notice for the current generation of reactors in the United States. By the T.V.A.'s reckoning, these were the last nuclear units still under construction in the nation. The T.V.A. once had the most ambitious nuclear program in the country, with 17 reactors on order. But as it turned out, the agency built only five nuclear units, of which only three are currently operating.

title: Journal; The Key to the City
description: On New Year's Eve, thousands of revelers, tourists and scoundrels will once again gather in Times Square to watch the ball drop, and millions more will watch on TV. Why? The ball is but a bauble, the neighborhood a has-been. Its gaudy signs aside, the intersection of Broadway and 42d Street has long been an urban blank, sparsely populated by fast-food and electronics outlets and the last remaining peep shows.

title: Wounded Rap Artist Avoids Jail, for Now
description: Tupac Shakur, the wounded rap performer convicted of sexual abuse charges, was allowed yesterday to stay free for at least another week for medical reasons, even as the judge in the case sent Mr. Shakur's co-defendant to jail pending sentencing.

title: The Fed's Making War on the Business Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Party Breaks Ranks With Premier
description: One of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's coalition partners revolted against the Government in Parliament today, feeding the division within an administration that was supposed to lead Italy into a new era.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies General Mills plans to split the company in two, dividing its food and restaurant businesses. Wall Street analysts praised the plan to spin off the restaurant operations to shareholders. [ Page D1. ] As it completes two hefty purchases, Forstmann Little is now expected to turn to refilling its war chest. Private investors familiar with the company's plans say it will look for roughly $2.5 billion in fresh capital in January. To succeed, its founding partner, Theodore J. Forstmann, must convince Wall Street investors that he can still get the best deals. [ D1. ] The Transportation Secretary ordered a safety audit of the nation's airlines and a speeding of new rules, which would essentially force commuter airlines to meet the same stringent standards as those for leading carriers. [ A1. ] A hearing on whether a class-action suit against tobacco companies should be allowed brought out some big legal guns in a New Orleans courtroom. A potential liability of an estimated $100 billion may be at stake for cigarette manufacturers. [ D2. ] Ameritech will acquire a top security monitoring company. [ D2. ] National Health Laboratories and Roche Biomedical Laboratories plan a $1.79 billion merger. [ D4. ] AT&T won a $1.2 billion contract for a 17,000-mile undersea fiber optic cable, linking Britain and Japan. [ D4. ] "Santa got spammed" -- Internet lingo for bombarded with electronic mail -- as eager programmers apparently misunderstood an offer involving corporate donations to charity. [ D4. ] Nike Inc. agreed to pay $395 million for Canstar Sports of Canada, a leading manufacturer of ice skates and hockey equipment. [ D4. ] Philip Morris's chairman will retire on Feb. 1. Geoffrey C. Bible, the chief executive, will replace R. William Murray. [ D5. ]

title: Food Giant Will Split Operations
description: General Mills Inc., the cereal company that during the 1980's became one of the nation's leading restaurateurs, said late today that it would split into two companies when its chairman and chief executive, H. Brewster Atwater Jr., retires next June.

title: Lumber Prices Fall on Fears Of Decline in Housing Starts
description: Lumber prices fell sharply yesterday on expectations that higher interest rates would cause housing demand to slow.

title: Ranking Bus Official Resigns Under Pressure
description: The top official in charge of New York City's bus service resigned yesterday under pressure from the Transit Authority's president, who said he was dissatisfied with the deteriorating quality of the service.

title: Australians Find Trees of Dinosaur Vintage
description: In a remote rain forest in Australia, scientists have found a grove of tall conifers that seem to be living fossils from the time of dinosaurs. They are trees of a kind paleobotanists thought had gone into extinction long ago, and their discovery is being hailed as an important link to prehistoric plant life.

title: 15 Dreams Came to End In Crash of Flight 3379
description: They were typical commuter airline passengers: business executives, college students on break and people visiting relatives for the holidays, traveling from Greensboro, N.C., to the hub at Raleigh-Durham, where they were to catch connecting flights onward. One talented young passenger had just achieved his dream.

title: JAZZ
description: With a Sense of Humor And Substitute Lyrics Clark Terry, trumpeter and fluegelhornist Village Vanguard

title: AT&T Is Awarded Contract To Lay Fiber Optic Cable
description: AT&T has been awarded a $1.2 billion contract to lay the longest undersea fiber optic cable system, 17,000 miles of cable connecting Britain and Japan, the company said yesterday.

title: AT HOME WITH: Camille O. Cosby; A Private Woman, A Public Cause
description: CAMILLE O. COSBY, a study in serene elegance, sat poised in front of a darkened television set in the living room of her East Side town house. It was a rare moment of quiet reflection in an otherwise hectic day.

title: INSIDE
description: Alien Law Is Blocked

title: Uniroyal Tech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included $ 47,000 for the quarter and $ 599,000 for the year in reorganization professional fees, $ 102,000 in environmental expenses for both periods, and $ 2,000 in the quarter and $ 6,761,000 in the year from recovery of pension expense. The year also included a $ 1,176,000 insurance settlement and an extraordinary credit of $ 727,000, or 5 cents a share.c-Included $ 309,000 in reorganization professional fees.d-Net loss, which included $ 905,000 in reorganization professional fees, $ 696,000 in environmental expenses and a $ 1,596,000 insurance settlement.(Loss)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC. (CC,N)
description: Circuit City Stores Inc., a leading consumer-electronics discount retailer, said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 46 percent on a 38 percent gain in sales.

title: Sports of The Times; The Attitude Check Begins With Riley
description: LET'S hypothesize that Ernie Grunfeld swings a deal late tonight. He trades Anthony Bonner and Hubert Davis for the physical shooting guard Pat Riley says the Knicks sorely need. We'll even give the player a name. Call him Otis Elevator.

title: Two Rivals And Acme Are Back In Business
description: For 30 years, two of America's most ferocious rivals have, like the figures on Keats's Grecian urn, remained frozen in time, the one in hot pursuit, the other a blithe step ahead. Now for the first time since the cartoon "War and Pieces," which was made in 1964, Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner resume the chase in "Chariots of Fur."

title: Carter Says He May Travel To Bosnia as Private Envoy
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said tonight that he had held talks with Bosnian Serb emissaries and might travel to Bosnia soon as a private mediator to promote a peace settlement.

title: A 'Tombstone Mentality'?
description: Critics have accused the Federal Aviation Administration of failing to tighten safety standards until a fatal crash forces the agency to react. News analysis, page B18.

title: Oklahoma State Hires a Black Coach
description: BOB SIMMONS, passed over for the head coaching job at Colorado, is the choice of Oklahoma State officials to lead the Cowboys' struggling football program. The university president, JAMES HALLIGAN, said yesterday that Simmons, 46, would be appointed to replace PAT JONES tomorrow. Jones resigned last month after 11 seasons, the final 6 of those losing years.

title: Essay; 'And Enjoy This'
description: Hence, loathed Melancholy! The whimpering of shell-shocked losers has ebbed, the gloating of sore winners has waned, and the season of the happy Warrior is at hand.

title: Dow Gains 30.95 on Price and Factory Data
description: In unusually heavy trading, the stock market rallied across the board yesterday, defying many analysts' expectations that stock prices would fall.

title: Cubs Sign Young for Half a Season
description: The Chicago Cubs yesterday signed pitcher ANTHONY YOUNG to a one-year contract. The 28-year-old right-hander appeared in 20 games for the Cubs last season after being acquired in a trade with the Mets. He was 4-6 with a 3.92 earned run average. On Aug. 15, Young had surgery on his right elbow. He is expected to be ready to pitch by midseason. (AP)

title: Topps Co.(TOPP,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Political Memo; Racial Questions Prove Persistent for Whitman
description: New Jerseyans who like her politics and those who don't at least agree that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is a master at winning support for her views. Only in her relations with blacks and some other minorities has the Governor been unable to shake off a persistent chorus of complaints that she is unresponsive to them -- and too responsive to the conservative wing of her Republican Party.

title: After Summations in Carjacking Trial, Spectators Fight in Courtroom
description: Summing up after a turbulent 37-day trial, a prosecutor said today that Edward L. Summers acted entirely alone in stealing a Jeep at the Nanuet Mall on Jan. 3 and killing its teen-age driver, while defense lawyers said the real killer was a Bronx barber and convicted drug dealer named Deno Lloyd.

title: Low-Tech Sci-Fi Is Not an Oxymoron
description: In a surging sci-fi present of Internets and juggernaut "Star Trek" projects, "Earth 2" is so technically modest that it seems to want little more than a friendly chuck under the chin. And NBC may well oblige if the new Sundays-at-7 series continues to orbit in a steady survival pattern against CBS's aged smash-hit "60 Minutes."

title: Bad-Weather Warnings On Commuter Flights
description: Although traveling by propeller plane remains safer than driving, aviation experts say that taking such planes in foul weather, particularly at night, can be hazardous.

title: Deputy Tells Of Emotions Of Simpson
description: Hinting tantalizingly at a confession but curbed by the protections of the clergy-penitent privilege, a sheriff's deputy today described an emotional jailhouse exchange between two former football greats divided by circumstance and Plexiglass. On one side was O. J. Simpson, who stands accused of two murders. On the other was Roosevelt Grier, an ordained minister who had come to counsel him.

title: Tax Chores Arise For Self-Employed
description: SORRY to intrude on the holiday festivities with talk of income taxes, but there are several chores to take care of before Jan. 1 in order to pay the Internal Revenue Service less by April 15.

title: A Venture for Cummins
description: The Cummins Engine Company and Metra Oy of Finland said today that they were planning a joint venture to make diesel engines. The venture will be owned equally by the two companies and will develop a new generation of heavy diesel engines, the companies said. Cummins, based in Columbus, Ind., said the engines would be produced initially at a French factory operated by a Metra subsidiary.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc.(PDS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 1,295,000, or 11 cents a share, on loss from early retirement of debt and 10 percent senior notes, net of tax benefit of $ 555,000.c-Net loss, and the year included a nonrecurring charge of $ 3.5 million relating to sale of Chicago stores.(Loss)The 1994 year included a $ 1.5 million pretax charge ($ 1.1 million after tax, or 9 cents a share) relating to a proposed settlement of litigation. The period also included a $ 860,000 pretax charge ($ 600,000 after tax, or 5 cents a share) relating to a settlement with a third party provider.

title: The Yankees Make a Deal for an Ace in McDowell
description: The Yankees made a stunning trade late last night that could stabilize their starting rotation next season and beyond when they made a deal for the former Cy Young Award winner Jack McDowell from the Chicago White Sox for Keith Heberling, a minor league pitcher, and a player to be named later.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 CARTER MAY GO TO BOSNIA Former President Jimmy Carter said that he had held talks with Bosnian Serb emissaries and might travel to the Balkans as a private mediator to promote a Bosnian peace settlement. A1

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about the effect of real-estate costs on the restaurant business misidentified a restaurant in San Francisco that is partly owned by Drew Nieporent. It is Rubicon, not Postrio.

title: Economic Scene; Yawns greet a warning about the burning fuse on entitlements.
description: CONGRESS is required to look five years ahead when it creates the Federal budget. But nobody is obliged to look to 2025 and beyond, when the all the expensive chickens that have been promised to the huge baby-boom generation -- the free medical care, the comfortable pensions -- come home to roost as the last of the generation hits retirement.

title: THEATER
description: Wide-Eyed Innocence To the Beat of Calypso 'Ballad for Bimshire' Players Theater

title: Salomon Will Start Selling Orange County Debt Today
description: Orange County yesterday began the slow, hard work of rescuing itself from the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history. In one sign of that effort, Salomon Brothers prepared to auction off the first $1 billion of the bonds that remain in the Southern California county's ill-fated investment portfolio.

title: Tarpley Suspended for One Game
