title: Some People (and Others) Are Truly Hard to Please; Cheeses, Neckties And Other Perks Of Being Mayor
description: UNDERSTAND this: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani does not want a gift from you. Unless, of course, it is fresh mozzarella.

title: U.S. Officials Voice Doubts On Truce Pact
description: While insisting that they welcomed any progress that former President Jimmy Carter might have made toward peace in the Balkans, Administration aides expressed some skepticism today about what he had accomplished.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: The Gold Standard For Girlhood Across America
description: "Some books are so familiar reading them is like being home again," Jo March observes in the new film version of Louisa May Alcott's classic novel. She's talking about Shakespeare, but we all know "Little Women" is a book like that, one of the most seductively nostalgic novels any child ever discovers. As the gold standard for American girlhood, it lingers in our collective consciousness as a wistful, inspiring memory. Ladies, get out your hand-hemmed handkerchiefs for the loveliest "Little Women" ever on screen.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; Breaking The Code
description: NINETEEN ninety-four may be the year when I refuse to give my wife a gift. This sounds harsh, but there's a reason for it: she cheats.

title: Cubans Welcome Envoys of Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Dept. Seeks Revised Law on Nuclear Cleanup to Focus on Riskiest Sites
description: The Energy Department will ask Congress next year to rewrite the rules on the cleanup of polluted nuclear arms factories, scrapping dozens of existing agreements with the states and focusing the program on the riskiest sites to try to save billions of dollars, top officials said today.

title: It's Smokestack Chic As Steelers Are Back
description: There were plenty of cigars in the Pittsburgh Steeler locker room here on Sunday afternoon. Long, expensive, fat ones that some players puffed and others simply held. Victory cigars.

title: Prudential Unit Getting More Cash From Parent
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America said yesterday that it would give its troubled securities subsidiary $365 million of new capital to help it defray the costs of settlements with tens of thousands of investors who were defrauded by the firm in the 1980's.

title:
HORSE RACING;
Jockeys Propose Races To Help Pay for Insurance
description: A series of six all-star jockey races at major race tracks to help pay for the riders' health insurance coverage was proposed yesterday by the Jockeys' Guild in response to the latest offer from the Thoroughbred Racing Associations.

title: Bills Gain On Inaction By the Fed
description: Prices of Treasury bills and notes rose yesterday as the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee adjourned its meeting without altering interest-rate policy.

title: Extension at T.C.U.
description: PAT SULLIVAN, who coached Texas Christian to a 7-4 record and its first bowl game in a decade, then pursued the Louisiana State job, signed a five-year contract extension yesterday. The school said he will get a substantial raise in a contract that contains a buyout clause and is designed to keep Sullivan at T.C.U. through 1999.

title: Intel's Crash Course on Consumers
description: It was during the weekend after Thanksgiving that Paul Otellini, the Intel Corporation's senior vice president for worldwide sales, first realized that his company had a crisis on its hands.

title: 3DO SHARES FALL AS COMPANY CUTS RESEARCH EFFORTS
description: Shares of the 3DO Company fell 10.9 percent yesterday after it said it was cutting back some research efforts so it could focus more on its CD-ROM video game system. The stock closed down $1.25 a share, at $10.25, in Nasdaq trading. A dismissed worker was quoted in The San Francisco Chronicle as saying that about 50 of the company's 300 employees had been released. A company spokeswoman, Cindy McCaffery, said the figure was too high. As part of a reorganization, 3DO cut back efforts to develop a car navigation system based on its technology, she said.

title: Florida's Plea for Immigration Relief Fails
description: In a troubling signal for states seeking relief from the costs associated with illegal immigration, a Federal District Court judge today threw out a lawsuit in which Florida officials sought to recover nearly $1 billion a year from the Federal Government to pay for services to illegal immigrants.

title: Standard Microsystems (SMSC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Nebraska's Frazier Makes Plans for Jan. 1
description: Taking quarterback TOMMIE FRAZIER off blood thinners so he may play for top-ranked Nebraska against Miami in the Orange Bowl on Jan. 1 is unusual but not unreasonable, doctors said yesterday.

title: AMOCO TO INCREASE CAPITAL SPENDING BY 27%
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it would increase 1995 capital spending by 27 percent to support its strategy of expanding overseas. The company said it planned to spend $4.2 billion next year, up from nearly $3.3 billion this year. More than half of the spending will go to so-called upstream projects intended to develop sources of crude oil and natural gas.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Welbilt Sets Merger Agreement
description: The Welbilt Corporation, the country's leading manufacturer of commercial cooking and heating equipment, agreed yesterday to a merger offer valued at $460.5 million by Berisford International P.L.C.

title: Alfred DiTolla, 68, Theater Union Head
description: Alfred W. DiTolla, the president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators, died on Tuesday at his home in Glen Rock, N.J. He was 68.

title: Chronic Back Problems Bring an End to Lendl's Career
description: Ivan Lendl, who made such a religion of physical fitness that he overcame a shortage of God-given tennis talent and transformed himself into the No. 1 player in the world for a record 270 weeks, announced his retirement today.

title: Macaulay Culkin's Poor Little Richie Rich Boy
description: Macaulay Culkin has reached that awkward age -- 14 -- when he is too old to play a moppet whose adorability redeems a mania for mischief and too young to jump on a motorcycle with Drew Barrymore. Perched on the brink of puberty in "Richie Rich," a movie based on the popular comic strip, the young actor seems wary and introverted, as though compelled to hoard his energy until the full rush of adolescence strikes.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; The Simpler, The Better
description: NEVER did I imagine that my lifelong and seemingly insatiable quest for my elegant and, of course, ageless mother's approval would crystallize in a banal blue suitcase on wheels.

title: Don't Let Them Tax Whatever Is Bad for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Gap Widened In October
description: The American economy pulled in a record amount of imported goods in October as the nation's trade deficit with Japan soared to a new peak of $6.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN CLASSIC VOYAGES CO., Chicago, appointed Phillip Calian executive vice president and chief operating officer. AMERICAN SUPERCONDUCTOR CORP., Westborough, Mass., named Ramesh Ratan to the new position of executive vice president for corporate development and chief financial officer, effective Jan. 4.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about military readiness at Fort Riley, Kan., misstated the amount of money the base diverted to training from its base repairs budget. It was $2 million, not $2 billion.

title: No Headline
description: "There is a philosophy among the top-ranked managers that you can't touch top management. For some reason, they seem to think it would bring down the whole damn agency if you messed with a certain level of person." JAMES DORCY, ex-chief investigator for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. [ A1:5. ]

title: Stuart Levin, 64, an Operator Of Elegant Restaurants, Is Dead
description: Stuart Levin, who ran elegant Manhattan restaurants, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 64 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; Unlovely Year, Perfect Present
description: SINCE nothing good had happened to me all year, I was not counting on Christmas. I was the only 14-year-old girl on the Eastern Seaboard who could not talk to boys and could not grow breasts. No Santa was going to save my bacon.

title: Excerpts From the Ruling On Free Speech at Malls
description: Following are excerpts from the majority opinion in today's ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court on the distribution of leaflets in shopping centers.

title: Rebels in Mexico's South Vanish Before a Show of Force
description: Hundreds of state police officers reinforced by heavily armed federal soldiers pushed aggressively today into isolated territory that had been taken on Monday by rebel forces in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTIE BRINKLEY, the model, and RICKY TAUBMAN, a real estate developer, plan to be married tomorrow atop Telluride Ski Mountain in Colorado, reportedly in the presence of 150 guests and choirs flown in for the event.

title: U.S. Issues New Warning to North Korea Over American Fliers
description: The United States warned North Korea today that any further delay in releasing a captured helicopter pilot and the body of another could worsen relations at a time when the North has been eager to improve ties with the West.

title: Germany Shuns Biotechnology
description: Hoechst A.G., the pharmaceutical company, has poured $90 million into its biotechnology operations. Its rival BASF has opened an $80 million biotech research operation. And Bayer has just entered a $25 million biotech joint venture.

title: Ambulance Service Admits 'Miscommunication' in Death
description: When Emergency Medical Service ambulances answered a call for help in Rego Park, Queens, on Sunday night, they encountered a five-block scene of blood and frenzy that was chaotic even by New York standards. But as bullets flew past the ambulances, there was so much activity and so many injuries that emergency crews missed the original call to assist a wounded Chinese restaurant cashier who was rapidly bleeding to death.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; Meteorology Doesn't Count
description: SAN FRANCISCO has a winter nip year round. But at Christmas, it never looks like the holiday cards.

title: For Yeltsin, Bad News vs. Bad News
description: The Russian military, poised outside the secessionist capital of Grozny, could take the city at any time and is awaiting an order from President Boris N. Yeltsin. But it is uncertain when or if he will give it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: SCOTT TO BUY BACK SHARES AND TRIM DEBT
description: The Scott Paper Company said yesterday that it would use proceeds from the sale of nonstrategic assets to buy back $300 million of the company's shares and to reduce corporate debt $1.3 billion early next year. The company said it had completed the sale of its S. D. Warren coated-paper subsidiary to Sappi Ltd. of South Africa for $1.6 billion. Last week, Scott completed the sale of its energy complex in Mobile, Ala., for $350 million. The deals are part of a larger program to realize $3 billion in after-tax proceeds from the sale of nonstrategic assets, the company said.

title: Wausau Paper Mills Co.  (WSAU,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1,000,000, or 4 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Market Place; AK makes steel, and money, the old-fashioned way.
description: THE AK Steel Corporation is the newest name in basic steel, although its roots run deep. The company today is what is left of the carbon-steel division of Armco Inc., which now produces stainless and other specialty steels.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BAXTER INTERNATIONAL INC., Deerfield, Ill., completed the sale of its diagnostics products manufacturing businesses to Bain Capital for about $415 million. CHARTER MEDICAL CORP., Macon, Ga., said it would acquire Magellan Health Services Inc., Boston, for $54 million.

title: BOSNIA FOES AGREE TO 4-MONTH TRUCE, CARTER REPORTS
description: Jimmy Carter announced today that the warring parties in Bosnia had agreed to begin a nationwide cease-fire on Friday at noon that would last at least four months.

title: Volt Information Sciences Inc.(VOLT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from redemption of debt of $ 271,000, or 6 cents a share.c-Net loss and the year included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 959,000, or 20 cents a share.Latest year's income from continuing operations of $ 12,044,000, or $ 2.51 a share, included a second-quarter gain of $ 5,760,000, or $ 1.20 a share, from the sale of the company's 50 percent interest in a joint venture.(Loss)

title: Blind Eye: How the Immigration System Handles Discipline -- A special report.; Behind One Agency's Walls: Misbehaving and Moving Up
description: The harassment of Ginger Kramer began shortly after she took a job as an automation clerk in the Livermore, Calif., office of the Border Patrol. In a sworn statement to investigators, she said her boss, J. William Carter, crudely invited her to have sex on his office couch. She pushed him away as he tried to embrace her, she said.

title: Sports of The Times; Picture Still Clear For Beard
description: THE black-and-white snapshot is in one of Butch Beard's old photo albums, in the back of some closet. He is a 17-year-old high school senior, a college basketball recruit, posing stiffly with the big man on campus at the University of Kentucky.

title: McDowell Not Rushing Into Yanks Deal
description: Jack McDowell, one of the superb pitchers in the major leagues, turns 29 years old in less than one month. The next contract he signs could be the last lucrative multiyear deal of his career. So why should he rush and sign with the Yankees when the status of baseball is so unsettled?

title: MERGER PLANNED BY AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY SUPPLIERS
description: Mascotech Inc. agreed yesterday to merge its Mascotech Controls unit with Bitron Inc. and Saturn Electronics and Engineering Inc. Terms of the agreement among the automotive-industry suppliers were not disclosed. Mascotech, based in Taylor, Mich., said last month that it was considering a restructuring. Saturn Electronics and Engineering will retain a majority stake in the company, which will operate under the Saturn name and be based in Rochester Hills, Mich. Mascotech and Bitron, which is based in Rocky Mount, N.C., are to keep stakes in the company, Mascotech said. The company will have 800 employees and 8 factories. Mascotech said the merger would create one of the largest minority-owned auto industry suppliers in the United States.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; Best Revenge? Losing the Gift
description: I CAN'T find it anywhere.

title: Boys Town Costs No More Than Other Residential Youth Care
description: To the Editor:

title: CHASE SAYS IT EXPECTS LOWER TRADING REVENUE
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it expected its fourth-quarter trading revenue to be lower than in the third quarter. Falling stock and bond prices could affect the profits of all big banks, which over the last decade built trading operations to supplement traditional businesses like lending. Bankers Trust also cited trading revenue in its projections of lower earnings. Diane B. Glossman, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers, said trading revenue at Chase Manhattan in the fourth quarter would probably fall to $110 million from $188 million in the third quarter. Chase trading revenue declines will be "partially offset" by gains from other businesses, a spokesman, John Anderson, said. Shares of Chase were unchanged at $35.

title: Dime Merger Is Cleared
description: Dime Bancorp Inc. said on Monday that it had received final clearance for its $850 million merger with Anchor Bancorp Inc. The approval by the Office of Thrift Supervision, a Federal agency that oversees savings and loan institutions, is the final hurdle for the merger, which was announced last summer. The merger should be completed next month. Each common share of Anchor will be converted into 1.77 newly issued shares of the merged company, while each share of Dime will be converted into one share.

title: For Dancers and Stage Managers With Ballet Theater, a New Voice
description: The American Guild of Musical Artists first took dancers under its wing in 1939. Today, 1,000 of its 5,500 members are dancers and the union represents 24 ballet and modern-dance companies. But the guild lost a major constituent when the 75 dancers and stage managers of American Ballet Theater broke away in June and then voted this month to ratify a contract negotiated by a new union, the Independent Artists of America, which represents only Ballet Theater.

title: Book Notes
description: Fast-Moving Club

title: COURT PROTECTS SPEECH IN MALLS
description: Declaring that shopping malls have replaced the parks and squares that were "traditionally the home of free speech," the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the malls must allow access to protesters who want to distribute leaflets on social issues.

title: Executive to Leave DDB Needham Shop
description: Larry Iannuzzelli, a longtime executive at DDB Needham New York, said yesterday that he would leave at the end of the year to start his own consulting business.

title: N.Y.P.D. to Go on the Air
description: "N.Y.P.D. Blue" is about to face some new competition -- from the N.Y.P.D. itself.

title: C. M. Hubbard, 82, Ex-State Dept. Aide
description: Charlotte Moton Hubbard, who was deputy assistant secretary of state for public affairs from 1964 to 1970, making her the top-ranking black woman in the Johnson Administration at the time, died on Sunday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 82.

title: Mariner Health Group
description: Shares of Mariner Health Group, a health care service provider based in Mystic, Conn., dropped more than 11 percent yesterday in Nasdaq trading after its president and chief executive resigned with no public explanation.

title: Real Estate; The QVC Network finds a new home in a corporate park west of Philadelphia.
description: QVC NETWORK INC., which sells merchandise on its cable television channel, did a little old-fashioned bargain hunting of its own this year and wound up buying a 600,000-square-foot building for office and warehouse space.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Harboring a yen to step all over your ex-spouse's divorce lawyer? Well, now you can -- if that lawyer is RAOUL LIONEL FELDER and you happen to be on his Christmas list.

title: The Fed Forgoes a Seventh Rate Increase
description: The Federal Reserve's top officials met for nearly four hours today but adjourned without announcing any change in interest rates.

title: Wine Talk
description: NO one ventures too far into wine lore before hearing someone say: "Of course it's good. It's a first growth." Or, "It's only a fifth growth, but it should be at least a second."

title: NIKE'S SHARES RISE AFTER REPORT OF HIGHER EARNINGS
description: The shares of Nike Inc. rose 8.5 percent yesterday, a day after it reported its first earnings increase in six quarters. The stock climbed $5.625, to $71.625, after touching a 52-week high of $71.875. A year ago, the stock was trading at $43 a share. On Monday, Nike reported better-than-expected earnings of $84.9 million, or $1.16 a share, in the second fiscal quarter, up 62 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Food Notes
description: For Tasty Stockings

title: County Sets New Budget And Tax Rise
description: Battered by successful challenges to property assessments and by mandatory state programs, Westchester County has adopted a budget for next year that, on average, will raise county property taxes by 8.4 percent, the largest increase in four years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a survey's finding that doctors at many teaching hospitals learn techniques by practicing on people who have just died misstated an affiliation of Dr. George Kanoti. He is with the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, not Case Western Reserve University.

title: In Dishes From Soup to Hash, the Sweet Potato Shows Off
description: SOME people are divided into two factions during the holidays: the sweet potato pie camp and the pumpkin pie camp. "I like sweet potatoes better than pumpkins any day," said Norma Jean Darden, an owner of Spoonbread Catering in Manhattan.

title: Bosnian Serb Leader Offers His Revisions to Peace Plan
description: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, set out his ideas for radical changes to an American-backed international peace plan in a document he handed to former President Jimmy Carter today.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; So Who Needs Gifts?
description: TO whom it may concern: If you're even the least bit tempted to slip me a present -- Christmas, Hanukkah, whatever -- I have one suggestion: don't. I am difficult, nay, impossible, to gift. What I truly desire, not even the Gap can fulfill.

title: Morrison Restaurants Inc.(RI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: Year-ago sales included sales of some operations classified as discontinued.

title: No Charges in Death of Boy With Toy Gun
description: Saying the real culprits are authentic-looking toy guns, the Brooklyn District Attorney announced yesterday that he would not attempt to prosecute the housing police officer who shot and killed a 13-year-old boy last September after suddenly coming upon the boy playing cops and robbers.

title: Of Wise Men and Wise Guys; Wrapped Up In Anxiety
description: THERE is one holiday gift whose purchase causes me more anxiety than any other. Appropriately, it's the present for my psychotherapist.

title: French Team Pulls Out
description: One of two French America's Cup sailing teams has withdrawn its challenger's bid. ERNIE TAYLOR, executive director of the challengers' committee, said yesterday that the Yacht Club d'Antibes announced its withdrawal at a syndicates meeting Friday in San Diego. The group, Defi France, apparently had difficulty raising funds to support its multimillion-dollar effort, Taylor said.

title: DANCE
description: A Moody Blend Of Classical and Contemporary Fourth Dimension Dance Gould Hall

title: Personal Health
description: IT may lack the drama of drunken driving, but drowsy driving is even more common and can be just as deadly. Mix it with even one alcoholic drink and you have an asleep-at-the-wheel cocktail in the making.

title: Don't Let Them Tax Whatever Is Bad for Us; No Special Grace
description: To the Editor:

title: Frustration Growing As Knicks Fall Again
description: The Knicks lost again, this time to the short-handed Nets, who were without Derrick Coleman. John Starks lost his composure afterward. And New York will be losing Charles Oakley for an extended period because of toe surgery unless his condition improves within a week.

title: Reinventing the Soup Kitchen
description: GOLDIE KEY, a retired nurse who lives in Greenwich Village, was finishing lunch at One City Cafe, which just opened at 240 West 14th Street in Manhattan. She was pleased with her meal, she said, because "I can afford it, and the service is as good as you could want."

title:
At the Nation's Table: Orlando, Fla.;
Good Nutrition At Disney World
description: For 10 years, the musical "Kitchen Cabaret" at Walt Disney World's Epcot Center in Orlando, Fla., promoted ham and eggs for breakfast. But since the summer, a concert called "Food Rocks" has sent a more healthful message about food and fitness, with cartoon versions of music stars crooning renditions of rock 'n' roll classics.

title: Acclaim to Buy Iguana
description: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Iguana Entertainment Inc., which helped Acclaim develop two popular sports-based video games. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Iguana, based in Austin, Tex., has worked with Acclaim to develop two of its hottest-selling entertainment products, N.B.A. Jam and N.F.L. Quarterback Club.

title: ORACLE SYSTEMS CORP. (ORCL,N)
description: The Oracle Systems Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter net income rose 51.1 percent, exceeding most analysts' expectations.

title: Ruling on Newcombe
description: A Federal judge yesterday said he would dismiss a civil lawsuit involving claims that an advertisement produced for the Coors Brewing Company had misappropriated the likeness of DON NEWCOMBE, the former Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher.

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc.(APOG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 525,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Lawsuit Shatters Code of Silence Over Hazing at Black Fraternities
description: Somewhere between being beaten with a cane so hard that it broke, and between being pummeled, poked with needles and branded on his arms and chest with a red-hot iron, Wardell Pride had a numbing thought.

title: Players and Owners Still Remain Deadlocked Over Tax on Teams' Payrolls
description: As the players' strike matched the length of the abbreviated 1994 season, major league club owners turned to Jerry McMorris today as their latest hope for a settlement.

title: Insurance Rules Help To Prevent Oil Spills
description: To the Editor:

title: Reckless Hiring in Albany
description: Governor-elect George Pataki made a reasonable request when he asked Gov. Mario Cuomo last month not to burden the New York State budget with last-minute hiring. So it is dismaying to find that the Cuomo administration has gone ahead and hired hundreds of people anyway.

title: Little Women, Growing Up Then and Now
description: LITTLE WOMEN By Louisa May Alcott 502 pages. Little, Brown. $18.95. LITTLE WOMEN By Louisa May Alcott Illustrated. 527 pages. Everyman's Library Children's Classics/Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. DAUGHTERS On Family and Fatherhood By Gerald Early Illustrated. 234 pages. Addison-Wesley. $17

title: Czech Cache of Nuclear Material Being Tested for Bomb Potential
description: The nuclear material recently seized by Czech authorities may be the largest supply of bomb-grade uranium smuggled out of the former Soviet Union, American officials said today. But the officials said that Washington was still awaiting scientific confirmation that the material seized was weapons-grade.

title: The Old-Time Tax Movie
description: If you are in the middle class, you are clearly going to get a tax cut. But there are real questions as to whether this is an exercise in fiscal fantasy and what impact it will have on the nation.

title:
Of Wise Men and Wise Guys;
Father's Song Lives On
description: THE gift came from three men, some wiser than others, but all visitors to a strange land.

title: Unhindered by AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: AT WORK WITH: Kristina Gunnill; Madison Avenue Meets the Volga
description: IN this provincial city, once closed to foreigners because of its military plants, a Peace Corps volunteer named Kristina Gunnill has found both a cause and a second family.

title: Discount Auto Parts Inc.(DAP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Key Post Off-Limits To Gramm
description: In a quest for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996, there would be no better perch for Senator Phil Gramm of Texas than the Senate Finance Committee, which will be at the center of efforts to cut taxes and change the welfare system.

title: Analyst Says a State-Run Lilco Could Cut Electric Bills by 13%
description: A state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company could save customers up to 13 percent on their electric bills over the next four years, according to an analyst hired by the Long Island Power Authority.

title: CABARET
description: Nostalgic Movie Songs Of the 1930's, 40's and 50's Maureen McGovern, singer Rainbow and Stars

title: California Governor Sues To Void Motor-Voter Law
description: Gov. Pete Wilson asked a Federal court today to declare the National Voter Registration Act unconstitutional. Mr. Wilson argued that the act was another example of Congress's laying down a law that states must then enforce at their own expense.

title: Don't Credit F.D.R. With 'Happy Warrior'
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Arrest Son In Bathtub Murder
description: A 67-year-old Manhattan woman was found dead in a bathtub filled with scalding water yesterday after a dispute with her son, who was arrested and charged with second-degree murder, the police said.

title: New Look at Hypothetical Future of Ibsen's Nora
description: When Nora Helmer walks off the stage at the end of "A Doll's House," she slams the door on her husband, her children and her adolescent passion for macaroons. These are the peanuts with which, throughout her marriage to Torvald, she has indulged herself as the keeper of her own caged animal. The scene is usually played by a decisive Nora who holds her head high and her back straight and carries a small overnight bag that seems to contain nothing heavier than a handkerchief. No need for anything else.

title: Casino Gambling Issue Affects Deal for Garden
description: The National Basketball Association and the National Hockey League will probably require the ITT Corporation, which earlier this week agreed to buy Caesars World for $1.7 billion, to ban betting on their games once the company gains control of the Knicks and the Rangers.

title: An Act of Bravery
description: As people left the crowded Brooklyn-bound subway train at the Fulton Street Station in lower Manhattan, Denfield S. Otto, an off-duty transit officer, heard popping sounds like gunfire. Then the car went black except for flashes of orange and crimson flames.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Travels With Julia:

title: U.S. Wisely Avoids Waging Air War in Bosnia
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending the Korean Showdown
description: A navigational error by a U.S. Army helicopter crew and an overreaction by North Korean defenders have threatened to undo months of arduous negotiations to defuse tensions on the Korean Peninsula. Now North Korea has taken a step to defuse the crisis by repatriating the remains of the dead American crewman. But it should have released the surviving American crewman as well.

title: G.M. Raising Many Prices As Costs of Materials Rise
description: With steel and plastic costs rising and demand for vehicles still strong, the General Motors Corporation said today that it would raise the prices of almost half its cars and nearly all its light trucks on Jan. 3.

title: 15% Stake Is Sought In Teledyne
description: The holding company for the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company said yesterday that it would seek Government permission to acquire 15 percent of the common stock of Teledyne Inc. after Teledyne rejected an unannounced offer of about $1.2 billion made last month to buy the entire company.

title: ORACLE STOCK RISES ON SECOND-QUARTER RESULTS
description: Shares of the Oracle Corporation surged yesterday as investors showed that they were impressed with the 48 percent growth in the software company's second-quarter revenue. Oracle's results were released after the market closed on Tuesday. Shares of Oracle rose $3, to $42.375, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. The company said the rise in revenues was its sharpest in four years. Oracle reported that key data base sales rose 67 percent in the quarter. Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., reported second-quarter earnings of 32 cents a share, compared with 21 cents in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: McCann-Erickson Forms Global Board
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide said yesterday that it had formed a worldwide management board representing all areas of the agency.

title: Graduates of Smith Stand on Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14 ITALY'S PREMIER ON THE BRINK After seven months in office, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi indicated that he would resign in the face of a revolt within his governing coalition over his leadership. A1

title: Subway Service
description: Transit officials said last night that they did not anticipate any changes or delays in subway service today as a result of the firebombing at the Fulton Street station.

title: Schools Chancellor Agrees to Stay On for 2 Years
description: The Board of Education reached an agreement yesterday with Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines on a new two-year contract, offering Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani only the smallest concession on his demands that the Chancellor be held to specific performance goals.

title: M.T.A. Vote Puts New Fares In Question
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board voted yesterday to delay adopting a $5 billion operating budget for next year until after Governor-elect George E. Pataki takes office next month, leaving uncertain the fate of the authority's ambitious plan to establish monthly passes and free transfers between buses and subways.

title: Mr. Foyle Chooses Faulkner
description: College basketball coaches often sound like meat merchants at a cattle auction. The guy is a real horse. That's a professional body if ever I've seen one. Last spring, the coaches were salivating in the stands as Adonal Foyle -- an athletic 6 feet 10 inches, 260 pounds -- made the rounds of the post-season all-star games as one of the most sought-after high school players in the country.

title: A Novice Plunges Into CD-ROM Land
description: THE young entrepreneurs who created the personal computer industry have always shown a flair for the evocative hyperbole of salesmanship. In the late 1970's, when their smaller computers started to appear, they deftly called them personal computers. It made the infuriating machines sound friendly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELIZABETH H. DOLE, president of the American Red Cross and the wife of Senator Bob Dole, who will be the new majority leader, underwent surgery Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston to clear blockage in a major artery in her neck. The hospital listed her condition yesterday as good.

title: Top Farm Job Likely to Go To Lawmaker From Kansas
description: Representative Dan Glickman of Kansas, who lost his bid for re-election last month, is likely to be named the next Agriculture Secretary, possibly as early as Thursday, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a call for Congress to rewrite the rules on the cleanup of polluted nuclear arms factories referred incorrectly in some editions to the source of the request. It was the Energy Department, not the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Areas That Have the 50-Plus Enthusiasts in Mind
description: There is an accent on youth in the ski industry, as there is in everything else. But increasingly, resorts are finding that sports-minded seniors are staying north to ski rather than following the exodus south to play golf.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FIREBOMB EXPLODES IN SUBWAY CAR, INJURING AT LEAST 40 PASSENGERS A crude firebomb engulfed a subway car that had just pulled into a station in lower Manhattan, burning more than 40 passengers in a horrifying second and disrupting subway service to and from Brooklyn for hours. A1. A SUSPECT: A JOBLESS COMPUTER WORKER Within an hour of the explosion, a badly burned man identified by the police as Edward Leary, 49, was being investigated in the blast and a similar incident last week in Harlem. A1.

title: So Dangerous, And So Simple To Produce
description: The explosive used in yesterday's subway firebombing appeared to be a modified Molotov cocktail.

title: Graduates of Smith Stand on Their Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Dec. 13 about the symbiotic relationship between leaf-cutting ants and fungi referred incorrectly to Mitchell L. Sogin and Ulrich G. Mueller, authors of scientific papers on the subject. Each was named last on a list of authors, a distinction often reserved for the senior researcher, but in this case they were not the senior authors.

title: Architect of Health Plan Could Face Charges
description: A Federal district judge said today that Ira C. Magaziner, the chief architect of President Clinton's health plan, had given misleading testimony to the court, and he asked Federal prosecutors to determine whether the statements amounted to perjury or criminal contempt of court.

title: North Korea Returns the Body Of Downed U.S. Copter Pilot
description: North Korea today turned over the body of an American pilot who died when his helicopter went down four days ago north of the demilitarized zone, and indicated it would soon free the surviving pilot, Pentagon officials said.

title: How Kaposi's Sarcoma Behaves in AIDS Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: "The train just lit up. The flames were shooting out from the doors." -- OZELL LUCAS, describing the explosion on the New York subway. [ B6:1. ]

title: Korea Yields on Dead Pilot
description: North Korea handed over the body of an American who died when his helicopter went down, and indicated it would soon free the other pilot, who survived. Page A8.

title: Fresno State Extends Sweeney's Contract
description: Fresno State has extended Coach JIM SWEENEY's contract into the next century despite finishing this year with a 5-7-1 record, the worst season in his 17 years with the Bulldogs. The new contract runs through Jan. 31, 2000, Athletic Director GARY CUNNINGHAM said Tuesday. Sweeney's contract, which was extended for four years in April 1993, will pay him $87,840 annually. Sweeney, 65, is the nation's seventh winningest active coach with a 30-year record of 194-137-4. (AP)

title: LEVI STRAUSS RETAIL STORES GET F.T.C. APPROVAL
description: Levi Strauss & Company received approval from the Federal Trade Commission yesterday to open dozens of its own retail clothing stores, offering Levi's brand products. The ruling also clears the way for a joint venture between Levi Strauss, based in San Francisco, and Designs Inc., a retailer based in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Levi Strauss and Designs have been in talks to create a joint venture to open up to 50 retail outlets during the next five years in 11 Northeastern states and Washington, D.C. In addition, Levi Strauss said it planned to establish as many as 48 wholly owned Original Levi's retail outlets during the next three to five years.

title: College Hockey Report
description: Interference

title: Dow Up 34.65 As Trading Stays Brisk
description: Stock traders surprised even themselves yesterday by bidding share prices up in unusually heavy trading.

title: Imitating Armstrong As a Form Of Praise
description: The two programs of Louis Armstrong's music on Saturday and Monday nights, presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center as part of its series The Armstrong Continuum, clearly represented an enormous amount of work. Nearly 40 pieces were played, with Monday night's program at Avery Fisher Hall digging deep into Armstrong's rarely performed orchestral works and Saturday's at Alice Tully Hall working through the revolutionary early works of Armstrong and King Oliver, among others. It is difficult music, and not just for Armstrong's trumpet parts; the pre-swing rhythms are hard to make come alive, and the orchestral works, even the barest ones, were often complicated by show-biz virtuosity.

title: A Dublin Dreamer Confronts Reality
description: No writer was ever more urbane and sophisticated than Oscar Wilde, so it comes as a shock that Albert Finney has discovered Wilde's warm and fuzzy side. In "A Man of No Importance," Mr. Finney plays Alfie Byrne, a bus conductor in Dublin in the early 1960's. He wears Wilde's trademark green carnation while riding an emerald-green double-decker bus. He reads Wilde's plays and poetry aloud to his rapt passengers every morning, and he directs local productions of Wilde's plays at the parish hall. Mr. Carney, the rough-hewn butcher (Michael Gambon), usually plays the lead.

title: Frances Schuman, 81; Helped Public Radio
description: Frances Prince Schuman, the founding chairwoman of the National Friends of Public Broadcasting and the wife of the composer William Schuman, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: Kenneth J. Ludwig; Insurance Executive, 72
description: Kenneth J. Ludwig, an insurance executive, died on Friday at Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, L.I. He was 72.

title: The Neediest Cases; Opening Home and Hearts to Disabled Children
description: In Zafar Ahmed's native country, Pakistan, neglected children are usually sent to live with relatives. So when Mr. Ahmed heard about New York City's foster care system, he was intrigued.

title: Jean Stralem, 86, Philanthropist Known for Work With the Blind
description: Jean Ickelheimer Stralem, a New York philanthropist and art collector, died on Tuesday at her Manhattan home. She was 86 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: A Cease-Fire Called Winter Settles Over Bosnia
description: Nenad Tadic, a Bosnian Serb soldier, looked up today at the snow falling heavily on the mountains surrounding Sarajevo and said, "The weather would achieve a four-month cease-fire, with or without the politicians."

title: Designs for Cathedrals Provide a Cautionary Tale
description: ASPIRING master builders take note: not even a Renaissance architect could protect his work from temperamental clients, budget disputes or rivals.

title: Market Place; For Banks, Time of Reckoning
description: High-rolling hedge fund managers like George Soros were the first to disclose that they lost money in the plunging bond market this year. Then came Piper Jaffray and some others that run mutual funds. More recently, several municipalities, most notably Orange County, Calif., confessed to substantial losses from risky interest rate bets gone bad.

title: Firebomb Ignites in Subway Car, Hurting at Least 40
description: A crude, homemade firebomb engulfed a subway car in flames just after it pulled into a heavily traveled station in lower Manhattan yesterday, injuring more than 40 passengers in a few horrifying seconds and disrupting subway service to Brooklyn for hours.

title: American Theater Wing Awards Its '94 Grants
description: Twenty-nine theater companies, schools and organizations in the New York metropolitan area are the recipients of grants totaling $99,500 given this year by the American Theater Wing.

title: U.S. Easing Rules on Biotech Patents
description: The Government will no longer require drug companies to conduct clinical trials on humans before granting patents for biotechnology products, Clinton Administration officials and drug industry executives said today.

title: A Johnson & Johnson executive takes over the helm of a foundation devoted to educational links.
description: FOR only the second time since its founding, the Advertising Educational Foundation is changing top leadership.

title: Christmas on a Corporate Island; Chubb Creates Holiday Spirit, but a Trip to the Mall Is Nice
description: Moving to the countryside of New Jersey in the early 1980's, the Chubb Corporation, like any pioneer, tried to take everything that the members of its large corporate family would need.

title: Solomon Friedman Absorbing Agency
description: Solomon Friedman Advertising in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., said yesterday that it would hire Chato Hill, a longtime creative executive in the Detroit area, and absorb his agency, effective Jan. 1.

title: Economic Scene; Lower income taxes stimulate the economy. The sequel.
description: REMEMBER the Laffer curve? That was the back-of-the napkin illustration by the economist Arthur Laffer of his idea that in some cases lower tax rates actually increase government revenues. It inspired the immense rate reductions of the early Ronald Reagan era -- and later, the I-told-you-so chuckles from mainstream economists who never believed the rosy revenue forecasts.

title: NBC and HBO Outbid Fox, Renewing Wimbledon Pact
description: After several weeks of delays, NBC and HBO yesterday renewed their rights to the Wimbledon tennis tournament, beating out Fox. The combined five-year deal is worth an estimated $26 million to $28 million annually, at least 44 percent above the previous deal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about military readiness at Fort Riley, Kan., misstated part of the combat history of the First Infantry Division. It did not fight in the Korean War.

title: Mexico to Float Peso; Fiscal Crisis Grows
description: Mexico's economy was thrown into crisis as the Government abandoned its efforts to defend the peso and said it would allow the currency to float freely in value against the dollar. The move was expected to bring a sharp devaluation, new inflation and losses for Mexican banks.

title: Frederic Zeller; Sculptor and Writer, 70
description: Frederic Zeller, a sculptor and author of a book about his escape from Nazi Germany, died on Saturday at his home in Sag Harbor, L.I. He was 70 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Horizon Healthcare Corp.(HHC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Mexico was thrown into financial turmoil as the Government abandoned its efforts to defend the peso and announced that it would instead allow it to float freely against the dollar. [ D1. ] Canada's efforts to protect its cultural industries are generating fresh tensions with the United States. [ D1. ]

title: The Difficulty of Holiday Car Rentals
description: HEADING home for the holidays? Or taking a holiday vacation?

title: Moscow's Dangerous Game
description: Hundreds of miles south of Moscow, 40,000 Russian troops have surrounded Grozny, the capital of the breakaway republic of Chechnya. One-ton bombs are falling on simple wooden houses and decaying Soviet-era buildings, and tens of thousands of refugees are fleeing the war zone. Yesterday, as Russian troops tightened the siege of the city, evidently holding back from an all-out assault, President Boris Yeltsin promised the Chechen people economic aid once the fighting ended.

title: Competing Cuts In Budget Dismissed
description: A state judge tossed out both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed budget cuts and a competing set of reductions enacted by the City Council, while sidestepping any ruling on the Council's attempt to test its budgetary powers under the New York City Charter.

title: Italian Premier to Resign, Possibly Today, Aides Say
description: After seven months in office as the billionaire outsider who promised Italy an era of stability and renewal, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi indicated tonight that he would resign in the face of a revolt within his coalition.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD., Montreal, completed the sale of its building products divisions in the U.S. and Canada to Genstar Capital Corp., for about $120 million. AMERITECH CORP., Chicago, approved an increase of 4.2 percent in its quarterly dividend, to 50 cents a share, and the repurchase of up to 20 million shares during three years.

title: U.S. Wisely Avoids Waging Air War in Bosnia; War Crimes Tribunal
description: To the Editor:

title: A New President Is Picked for GE Capital
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had named Denis J. Nayden president and chief operating officer of its GE Capital subsidiary.

title: Governors' Mansions: The Lights Are On, Is Anyone Home?
description: WHEN New York State voters elected a new governor last month, many probably assumed that George E. Pataki would move his family into the gabled Queen Anne Executive Mansion perched high on a hill above the Hudson in Albany -- the one that 29 governors have lived in, that Nelson A. Rockefeller restored after a fire on the first floor in 1961, where Alfred E. Smith once kept monkeys, donkeys, a bear and a goat named Heliotrope.

title: Corrections
description: The Buy of the Week feature with the Food Notes column in The Living Section yesterday misstated the price for one and three-quarters ounces of Osetra caviar at Petrossian. It is $47, not $85.

title: Baseball Talks Are Collapsing as Impasse Nears
description: Demonstrating once again that it is not the salesman but the product he's selling, major league club owners and their striking players reached another bleak stage in their negotiations today. Talks between the two sides were in a state of virtual collapse, and the owners were poised to declare an impasse and implement a salary cap.

title: Sports of The Times; Garden Must Get Gambling Weed-Killer
description: IN the year 2000, if not before, a gambling casino at Madison Square Garden might be a sideshow to a Knick or Ranger game.

title: Guest Artists: 'Nutcracker' Tradition
description: George Balanchine used to invite guest artists into his "Nutcracker" at the New York City Ballet, and Peter Martins, the company's current artistic director, has continued the tradition.

title: Judge Voids Disputed Cuts Of Mayor and Council
description: A state judge yesterday tossed out both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed budget cuts and a competing set of reductions enacted by the City Council, while sidestepping any ruling on the Council's attempt to test its budgetary powers under the City Charter.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Robert Osborn Is Dead at 90; Caricaturist and Satirist
description: Robert Osborn, the caricaturist, cartoonist and satiric commentator, died on Tuesday at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 90.

title: Essay; Middle-Class War
description: In the White House, the catch-phrase must have seemed like a good idea: Marry F.D.R.'s "Economic Bill of Rights" with Bill Clinton's campaign promise of a "middle-class tax cut" to dress up a necessary placation of the overtaxed as a "Middle-Class Bill of Rights."

title: Dean Rusk, Secretary of State In Vietnam War, Is Dead at 85
description: Dean Rusk, who as Secretary of State for President Kennedy and President Johnson became a stubborn if much-criticized defender of the American involvement in the Vietnam War, died Tuesday at his home in Athens, Ga., with his family at his side. He was 85.

title: Broderbund Software (BROD,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in November 1994.The latest first quarter also marked the initial contribution - $ 1.7 million in nonoperating income - from its 50 percent interest in Living Books.Also in the latest first quarter, Broderbund wrote off $ 1.6 million in assets remaining from the 1992 acquisition of PC Globe Inc. and recorded a pretax gain of $ 1.6 million as a result of the sale of an investment previously carried at no value.

title: Books of The Times; Flesh Turns Into Spirit, Fiction Into Grisly Fact
description: NEVERMORE By William Hjortsberg 289 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.

title: Accounts
description: * Follis Inc., New York, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $1.5 million: Crew Cuts, New York, a post-production house, and Kripalu Yoga, Baltimore, a yoga center. * Dialogic Corp., Parsippany, N.J., to Richardson, Myers & Donofrio, Baltimore, to handle its account, previously at Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Executive Director Is Leaving Post at Port Authority After 4 Years
description: In a move widely expected since the election of George E. Pataki gave both New York and New Jersey Republican Governors for the first time in decades, the Port Authority's executive director said yesterday that he would resign effective Feb. 3.

title: Variations on the Music Box
description: EVEN on a pop tune, each clear and delicate note in the song of an expertly made music box is like the chime of an Alpine church bell. This Swiss invention has always been a sweet holiday treat, not to mention a year-round sleep balm for restless infants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 19 about the growth of political power in the suburbs misstated the clientele of VNS, an organization that does exit polling, and misidentified Murray Edelman, a VNS executive. VNS carries out polls for ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, and The Associated Press, not for the Fox television network. Mr. Edelman is the editorial director of VNS, not its head. The article also misstated the voting record of Chelsea, Mass. Historically, the city has voted Democratic, not Republican.

title: The Sparring Is Over, for Now. Time for a Handshake.
description: AT FIRST there was an air of unreality about the afternoon as the sirens screamed outside, heading for the subway firebomb site in lower Manhattan, and reporters waiting for a news conference at Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn huddled around portable radios and telephones. Another New York City crisis had struck, making everything else seem insignificant.

title: Events: Crafts And Cactus
description: Kwanzaa Crafts American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West (79th Street); (212) 769-5315.

title: Salant
description: Shares of the Salant Corporation, an apparel maker, rose sharply yesterday. Dan Dorfman, a CNBC commentator, said that analysts had told him the company's stock could double to $10 from a recent price of $5, partly because of rising sales to Sears.

title: Els Is Named European Player of Year
description: ERNIE ELS of South Africa, the United States Open champion, was selected PGA European Tour player of the year yesterday.

title: Shelters Aren't Cause of Child Malnutrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Evelyn Shuckburgh, 85, Influential British Diplomat
description: Sir Evelyn Shuckburgh, a retired British diplomat, died on Dec. 12. He was 85 and lived in Watlington, Oxfordshire.

title: The Lamp With Subtlety
description: FROM its sleek, cast-aluminum body to its discreet maple base, the 23-inch-tall Marco table lamp brings an understated flair to a genre that can often be overwrought. "It's difficult to find a lamp that's easy to live with," said Michael Killeen, the design director of the J & R Collection, a Chicago company whose fashion-forward store furnishings are now manufactured for the home. "So many are overdesigned, premeditated. Even I'm guilty of that. But this time, it just felt right."

title: French Abbe Aids Homeless and Politicians Genuflect
description: Every year since 1954, as soon as the winter chill sets in here, a Roman Catholic abbot known to all of France as Abbe Pierre has emerged from his monastery in Normandy to demand publicly -- and often noisily -- that the authorities give shelter to the homeless.

title: Developer Charges Bribes Fed Boom in Brookhaven
description: In the mid-1980's, when John M. McNamara was using some of the hundreds of millions of dollars he was stealing from General Motors to develop real estate projects, Ira Costell would show up at Brookhaven Town Board meetings in futile attempts to persuade the town leaders to vote against Mr. McNamara's projects.

title: Oakley Tests Shoe And Knicks Test Mettle
description: While Charles Oakley issued a ray of hope about avoiding surgery, Pat Riley issued a strong warning to anyone who has written off the Knicks.

title: Cheating Death, and Testing a Reproductive Law
description: The birth of Judith Christine Hart on June 4, 1991, had been a lonely miracle. Later, as Nancy Hart filled out the hospital form to legally register her daughter's birth, one fill-in-the-blank made her pause.

title: Political Gifts Cost Prudential
description: In the largest civil settlement in its 19-year history, the Federal Election Commission announced today that Prudential Securities Inc. had agreed to pay $550,000 for making illegal political donations over several years.

title: Paris Journal; Starved for Customers, the Bistros Die in Droves
description: Henri Miquel, the owner, knows what most of his regulars want. The early-morning customers at Le Dufrenoy, his bistro, wolf down croissants and espressos, sometimes laced with a burning shot of calvados. At midday, copious plates of beef stew or lentils with ham zip along the Formica-topped tables. Afternoons are for flirting students and lovers of pinball machines. The after-work crowd comes in to decompress.

title: Clinton Seeks Ties With Pope on Aid Groups
description: At a time of sharpening differences in Congress over the usefulness of United States foreign aid, President Clinton has written to Pope John Paul II proposing closer, formal cooperation between United States Government and Roman Catholic aid agencies to insure that aid reaches the people it is meant for, American and Vatican officials said today.

title: Cintas Corp.(CTAS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
People
description: * Marshall Karp, executive vice president and executive creative director at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, New York, and executive creative director at McCann Interactive, was named to head Compelling Content, a creative satellite spinoff shop that will develop advertising and programming concepts for McCann Worldwide.

title: We Couldn't Live With a Balanced Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: First Alert Shares Plunge as Chicago Faults New Detector
description: Shares of First Alert Inc. plunged 24 percent today after Chicago officials said the company's carbon monoxide detectors had "serious shortcomings" and vowed to revise a law requiring such detectors in homes.

title: Threat of Disruption in Oil Supply Is Eased
description: Enough oil tankers are obtaining the added insurance to be required by Federal law beginning next week that a threat of disruption to the country's oil supplies has been averted.

title: TV Sells All Things
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pack of Architects For a House of Cards
description: SHUFFLE the modernist deck with "Play Architecture," cards from the Finnish Building Centre that cut the master builders down to size -- though whether they would appreciate the joke is debatable. Mies van der Rohe is a grumpy-looking Queen of Spades, Michael Graves is the imperious King of Hearts and Bernard Tschumi is the dashing Jack of Clubs. Iconic 20th-century structures -- including the Schroder House by Rietveld and the Einstein Tower by Mendelsohn -- illustrate the numbered cards. The cards are $15.95 a deck from the Princeton Architectural Press, 37 East 7th Street, New York 10003; (800) 458-1131.

title: One Man's Impromptu Act of Bravery
description: Denfield S. Otto, an off-duty transit officer sitting in the sixth car of the Brooklyn-bound train, was 45 minutes late for a transit police choir practice when he heard a popping sound like gunfire and looked toward the end of the car.

title: Coffee Shops Now Fill Tirana's Boulevard of Heroes
description: The grand boulevard that is this bedraggled capital's main street has sprung to a life it never knew before.

title: Investigation Finds 'Complex Network' Of Ticket Scalping
description: A New York State investigation into ticket scalping has found "a massive, complex network" that illegally resells tickets to major entertainment and sporting events for huge profits. But Attorney General G. Oliver Koppell acknowledges he will have been unable to do much about it before he leaves office on Dec. 31.

title: I.R.S. Angers Family of Pan Am Crash Victim
description: The Internal Revenue Service has notified the family of a man killed in the Pan Am jetliner crash in Scotland in 1988 that his estate faces a tax bill of more than $6 million on the settlement of a lawsuit against the now-defunct airline and its insurers, even though no payment has been made to the estate and the size of the settlement has not even been determined.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Says It Has Control of Borden
description: It has been a wild, bumpy ride for Elsie the Cow. But yesterday, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company announced that it had won control of Borden Inc. when stockholders tendered 63.5 percent of Borden's shares by the deadline of midnight Tuesday.

title: A Movement Disastrous Or Just Annoying?
description: At moments, all eight participants in tomorrow night's "Firing Line" debate seem to be ganging up on Gloria Steinem, who, unfortunately for the spirit of the occasion, is not there to speak for herself. The resolution, framed by William F. Buckley Jr., is "The Women's Movement Has Been Disastrous," and the two sides pretty much agree that pronouncements equating sex with rape and the campaign for the depatriarchizing of English ("spokesperson") are extreme, silly and uneuphonious. But there is strenuous disagreement over whether such annoyances constitute a disaster.

title: Mariners Re-sign Buhner for $15.5 Million
description: JAY BUHNER, a free agent who had been pursued by the Baltimore Orioles, has re-signed with the Seattle Mariners for $15.5 million over three years. The 30-year-old outfielder hit .279 last season with 21 homers and 68 runs batted in and has averaged 25 homers and 80 r.b.i. over the last four seasons.

title: Administration Gives Up On Raising Grazing Fees
description: The Clinton Administration reversed itself today and decided not to increase the fees paid by ranchers whose sheep and cattle graze on public lands.

title: Behind the Bearhug: Chechnya's Case
description: So why shouldn't Chechnya be independent?

title: N.H.L. Players Rally Against Payroll Tax Plan
description: Two hundred and forty players met for about three hours here on Day 82 of the lockout to discuss their collective bargaining struggle with the National Hockey League.

title: Judge Approves Plan for Logging In Forests Where Rare Owls Live
description: A Federal judge today approved the Clinton Administration's much-disputed plan for logging in the Pacific Northwest forest that is home to the spotted owl and other imperiled species.

title: Commercial Metals Co.  (CMC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: LIFO method of inventory valuation reduced net income by $ 73,000, or 1 cent a share, in the latest quarter, and by $ 647,000, 4 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.The company said a one-time charge for litigation cut net income by $ 4.1 million in the latest quarter, but was partially offset by a $ 1 million credit from favorable resolution of tax issues.

title: Loved Ones Live On in Black and White
description: WHEN I look through my family photographs, I am struck by the power of the portraits from the past. The strongest images are printed in sepia -- my grandmother, posed at 13, in her nipped-in "waist" and long skirt, her head held high under a wide, plumed hat. Her portrait has faded on its board-like paper, but her image still bears out her boasts of an hourglass figure and a face that men fell in love with at first sight. I can hear her voice as I stare at her picture, telling how her future husband saw this photograph on the wall and raced across the room to declare, "If I can't marry this girl, I will marry no one at all."

title: Treasuries Mixed, but Auction Helps
description: Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with prices helped by a well-received auction of two-year notes and by a stronger dollar.

title: Brooks Hits Hard, With No Apologies
description: The former Jets wide receiver Al Toon had so many concussions during his eight-year career that another one could have put his health in serious jeopardy. So he left the game. And it turns out that the last big hit he took before walking away came from, of all people, a current Giants player.

title: Tassels As Stars
description: OVERSIZE accessories make even the skimpiest curtains look glamorous. At least that's the philosophy of Xavier Dohr, a Parisian designer. His window accessories combine the suavity of Jean-Michel Frank with the utilitarianism of the Gap. Priced from $190 to $375, they are available to the trade at Quadrille, 979 Third Avenue (near 58th Street); (212) 753-2995.

title: Hospital Endowment From Ashe Unit
description: The Arthur Ashe Foundation for the Defeat of AIDS will establish a $1 million endowment at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York, the foundation president and late tennis star's widow, JEANNE MOUTOUSSAMY-ASHE, said yesterday. (AP)

title: Shaken, but Reassured
description: New Yorkers suffered a harrowing flashback yesterday when a crude firebomb ignited on a subway car in lower Manhattan, injuring more than 40 people and spreading fear that the World Trade Center bombing was being played out again in the subways. Some injuries were severe, but the outcome was less horrific than it might have been.

title: Good Deeds In Minutes
description: TOO busy to volunteer, too cash-strapped to write a check? Reconsider the options. "How to Make New York a Better Place to Live: A Handbook for Resident Angels" (City & Company, $9.95) by Mark Grashow offers 540 suggestions for low-effort, high-impact activism. The opportunities range from the usual to the quirky, in all boroughs: donating used eyeglasses, mending clothes at a nursing home, even participating in a fish census at a Staten Island salt marsh.

title: Poor Steered To Yonkers, Mayor Charges
description: Charging that wealthy suburbs have illegally steered poor people to housing in Yonkers, Mayor Terence M. Zaleski threatened today to sue 11 Westchester communities, the county and the Federal Government unless they moved to stop the practice.

title: Microsoft Venture With Cable Giant
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would invest $125 million for a 20 percent stake in the Microsoft Corporation's planned on-line service.

title: AUSTRALIAN CONCERN TO ACQUIRE PARENT OF FORMICA
description: BTR Nylex Ltd., an Australian plastics company, said early today that it would acquire FM Holdings Inc., the parent of the Formica Corporation, for $800 million (Australian), or $621 million. Formica, based in Wayne, N.J., designs and manufactures decorative laminates and other surfacing products worldwide under the brand names Formica and Sureil. It is the world's largest producer of high-pressure decorative laminates. It employs 3,400 people and has plants in the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Spain, Germany and Taiwan. The purchase price includes the assumption of about $440 million (Australian) in debt.

title: Police Bullet Killed Victim Of Gun Battle
description: Police officials and the New York City Medical Examiner's office have determined that a bystander who died on Sunday in a furious gunfight between police officers and a gunman in Queens was killed by a bullet fired by the police, not by the gunman.

title: N.C.A.A. Places Alcorn State on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has placed Alcorn State University's athletic program on probation for three years for violations committed in the football and men's and women's basketball programs.

title: Continental Homes Holding Corp.(CON,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Morris Helps Upstart Nets Keep Rolling
description: Only a rookie, Grant Hill is already being called the next Michael Jordan by some. The Detroit Pistons' forward came into tonight's game against the Nets as the leading vote-getter in the balloting for the N.B.A. All-Star Game. But tonight -- at least for one night -- it was the Nets' Chris Morris, not Hill, who looked like Mike.

title: Rockies Re-sign Freeman for 2 Years
description: The Colorado Rockies have re-signed right-hander MARVIN FREEMAN to a $4.4 million, two-year contract. Freeman, 31, was 10-2 with a 2.80 e.r.a. last season after joining the Rockies as a free agent. (AP)

title: AT HOME WITH: Mary Bingham; Cultural Gifts Shared With a City
description: MARY BINGHAM lives alone in an Italianate villa at Melcombe, the newspaper family's estate 15 minutes outside Louisville, Ky. Surviving traumas as well as tragedies, she remains vigorous and self-composed. On Christmas Eve, she celebrates her 90th birthday.

title: Big Board's Uncovered Short Sales Set Record
description: The American exchange reported a 1.4 percent decline, to 111.21 million shares, from an adjusted 112.69 million shares reported in mid-November.

title: One, by One, by One, Manhattan Marches On
description: Coach Fran Fraschilla of Manhattan has a motto his players are sold on. "We want to start a one-game winning streak with every game," he said. "That's all we ever care about."

title:
HORSE RACING;
Jockeys Reject Offer and May Join Sports Picket Line
description: Negotiations between the Thoroughbred Racing Associations and the Jockeys' Guild over insurance financing reached an impasse yesterday, and with time running out before the current contract expires on Dec. 31, the nation's leading riders could join baseball players and hockey players on the sidelines on Jan. 1.

title: Ashkenazy Drops Out of Orchestra
description: The pianist and conductor Vladimir Ashkenazy has resigned as music director of the Royal Philharmonic in a dispute with the orchestra's management over its offer to a potential successor.

title: Gingrich Gets Big Contract From Publisher
description: Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican who will be the next Speaker of the House, is expanding his literary career in a multimillion-dollar deal with the book publisher Harper Collins.

title: Journal; A Star Is Born
description: "Dueling Tax Cuts," Washington's newest drama, made its debut last Thursday with the President's prime-time address from the Oval Office. But as so often happens in show business, a supporting player stole the show from the star. Sitting casually on a desk and speaking a scant five minutes, the nation's newest Senator, Fred Thompson of Tennessee, delivered a G.O.P. rebuttal that had all the focus, intimacy and conviction that Mr. Clinton's impersonation of a Republican lacked.

title: Hillhaven Corp.(HIL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included $ 8.1 million pretax gain from the sale of a minority interest in an institutional pharmacy and about $ 1 million in nonrecurring costs associated with acquisitions in both the quarter and 6 months and a charge of $ 52,000 on early extinguishment of debt in the quarter and $ 174,000 in the 6 months.c-Included a $ 21,904,000 pretax credit from reserves unused at the completion of its disposition program and a charge of $ 940,000 for early extinguishment of debt in both the quarter and 6 months.Year-ago quarter, lastest 6 months and year-ago results are all restated to reflect the acquisition in October 1994 of CPS Pharmaceutical Services Inc. and Advanced Infusion Systems, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: In Japan, Girls Lead the Digital Pack
description: Apple Computer Inc.'s personal digital assistant, the Newton, didn't exactly catch on with American businessmen. Maybe the company should have focused on Japanese girls instead.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Canada Plans Tax on a U.S. Magazine
description: Canada's efforts to protect its recording and magazine industries at the expense of powerful American companies are generating fresh tensions with the United States.

title: A Bicycle With an Edge -- And Electric, at That
description: YOU say you like the idea of bicycling but find the ride a little too long, the hills a little too steep or the trip a little too sweaty? Specialized Bicycle Components, the bicycle company of Morgan Hill, Calif., is working on a model with an electric motor to help with the pedaling.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL No. 8 Florida Is Upset Kip Stone scored 24 points, 9 in the final 4 minutes, in visiting Jacksonville's 68-67 upset of eighth-ranked Florida last night. Jacksonville led most of the game despite shooting only 39 percent from the free throw line and turning the ball over 21 times. Jacksonville (5-2) opened an 8-point lead four times in the second half, but Florida (5-2) came back behind guard Dan Cross (28 points, 15 rebounds) and forward Andrew DeClercq (26 points). Cross and DeClercq scored 20 consecutive points, including all of a 10-0 run with less than 10 minutes to play, as Florida took a 60-57 lead. (AP) California 89, Cincinnati 76: Monty Buckley (22 points) and K. J. Roberts (16 points) sparked a second-half comeback by No. 24 California (6-0) in its victory at No. 13 Cincinnati (7-3). California overcame an 8-point deficit for its second consecutive victory over a ranked team. The Golden Bears beat then-No. 11 Minnesota, 82-75, last Saturday. (AP)

title: New Element, 111, Is Detected By German Nuclear Scientists
description: A team of German physicists reported on Tuesday that they had succeeded in creating, detecting and identifying three atoms of a new element. Although the atoms survived for less than two-thousandths of a second, scientists hailed the achievement as a landmark in nuclear physics.

title: A Surprise From Lichtenstein Prints Show
description: The unexpected news delivered by the handsome retrospective of Roy Lichtenstein's prints at the National Gallery of Art here is that his graphic works are as good as his paintings, sometimes better. One might have expected exactly the opposite from this Pop artist, famous for recyling images from both high and low culture into pristine, expertly composed icons of style. Since Mr. Lichtenstein's painted images are so seamless and devoid of touch as to seem almost like prints themselves, it might be supposed that his prints seen in bulk might easily impress one as not only redundant but also icy cold, too far removed from the artist's already invisible hand.

title: 10 Writers Win Grants
description: The Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund announced 10 winners of its annual Writer's Awards on Tuesday. The recepients, who will receive $105,000 each, to be paid in three annual installments, are Sherman Alexie, Christopher Durang, Ian Frazier, Jessica Hagedorn, Bell Hooks, June Jordan, W. S. Merwin, David Mura, Lee Smith and Wakaka Yamauchi. Under the terms of the award, the winners will work with nonprofit cultural and community organizations to create programs intended to foster a greater appreciation of contemporary literature.

title: Hasty Is Wearing the Frustration of the Jets' Failure on His Sleeve
description: Seven seasons as a Jet suddenly seemed too much today for James Hasty, the volatile, outspoken cornerback who had a sideline confrontation with a teammate last Sunday.

title: From Burns and Tatters, a Bombing Suspect
description: The man in the Clark Street subway station in Brooklyn was hurting.

title: Don't Veto the Police Commission
description: Nearly everyone agrees that New York City needs an independent agency to monitor police corruption. But the Mayor and the City Council have been unable to agree on what powers such a commission should have.

title: Anti-Abortion Violence Rises Slightly, Study Finds
description: Violence at abortion clinics this year has risen only slightly from last year, according to a survey by an abortion rights group, although the group also found that clinics were experiencing a sharp increase in death threats.

title: It's Down to the Wire; McMorris Is at Plate
description: Some call him a deal maker, others call him a decision maker. Only time will tell if Jerry McMorris is much more than that when it comes to helping his fellow baseball owners and major leaguers as they desperately try to wend their way out of a paralyzing four-month-old players strike.

title: WTA Tour Headquarters to Connecticut
description: The WTA Tour, the governing body of women's professional tennis, will move its world headquarters to Stamford, Conn., in February, Gov. LOWELL P. WEICKER Jr. said yesterday. The WTA Tour has been based in St. Petersburg, Fla., since 1990 and will continue to maintain an operations office there. WTA officials said Connecticut offers a better business environment than Florida for its headquarters. The move is also part of an effort to restructure the WTA Tour by merging with the staff of the New York City-based Women's Tennis Council. The new headquarters will employ about 10 people, including the WTA Tour's chief executive officer, ANNE PERSON WORCESTER. (AP)

title: The Pop Life
description: Old, New and Odd

title: Embattled Yeltsin Finds He Is Also Besieged at Home
description: Russian troops are still laying siege to Grozny, the capital of secessionist Chechnya, while in Moscow, opponents of the offensive are laying siege to the presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Report Finds the Limbo of Foster Care Is Growing Longer
description: Because one girl was beaten and sexually abused by her parents, she has been taken away from them three times, and placed with four different foster families. But nine years after she entered New York City's foster care system as an infant, she remains ineligible for adoption because her parents' legal claim to her still has not been cut off.

title: Frenzied Passengers, Their Hair and Clothes in Flames, Flee Burning Train
description: Through smoke, screams and heat, Mary McMurry tried to dash out of the packed subway train as soon as she heard the explosion and saw the flash of flames in the car behind her. But she was nearly knocked to the ground by the crush of people. When she reached the platform of the Fulton Street station, she went to the aid of three fellow passengers rolling on the ground, flames consuming their clothing.

title: Cigna Plans To Revamp Subsidiary
description: The Cigna Corporation was pushed yesterday to announce plans to reorganize its loss-ridden property and liability insurance business after the A. M. Best Company reduced Cigna's ratings to a level that would seriously limit the appeal of Cigna policies to corporations.

title: Bridge
description: During the 1993 Fall Nationals in Seattle, the diagramed deal appeared in this column, with East playing in a three-diamond contract. Mike Passell of Dallas, sitting South, underled the ace of spades, deceived the declarer and defeated the contract.

title: French Yacht Racer Arrives in Sydney
description: The French solo sailor Christophe Auguin arrived in Sydney, Australia, yesterday after having been stalled out for two days in light winds.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a museum in Chongqing, China, dedicated to Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, an American who served there during World War II, misstated his role in some copies. He commanded American forces in the China-Burma-India theater, not all Allied forces there.

title: HealthTrust Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Theatrical Readings Meant for the Holidays
description: Two of television's most meaningful productions this Christmas week take the now almost quaint form of theatrical readings. Talking heads still can have clout.

title: Council Votes To Eliminate Most Smoking In Public Sites
