description: By the time she reached the top of the cobblestone ramp leading out of the dungeon that was a door of no return for her ancestors, Doris Jenkins had to prop herself up against the whitewashed walls of this town's old slaving fort to collect herself.

title: Spurs Sign Rivers
description: DOC RIVERS, the 12-year veteran guard waived earlier this month by the Knicks, signed yesterday with San Antonio, saying the Spurs represented his best shot at playing on a championship team.

title: Why My Right to Own a Gun Must Endure
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaster Leaves Imprint on Town
description: In a few moments of unforgettable terror, a tornado roared into Lancaster one night last April, killing three people, destroying 280 houses and damaging many more. It literally tore out the heart of the town, transforming the quaint, 19th-century Town Square into mounds of brick and glass and dirt.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a quiet Christmas in Venezuela for RICK and KAREN DOBBERTIN, a New York State couple journeying around the world in a homemade amphibious vehicle.

title: Shelter the Homeless In Empty Alexander's
description: To the Editor:

title: They Fight City Hall on Taxes And They're Winning Refunds
description: Larry G. Willinger and Lionel Markusfeld are, as Mr. Willinger likes to put it, "just two guys using their heads."

title: Collectors Are a Threat To Some Rare Species, Government Aides Say
description: THE enforcers of the Endangered Species Act are moving to protect certain dwindling populations of rare animals and plants from some of the very people who cherish them most: collectors.

title: French Storm Jetliner, Free Hostages, Kill 4 Gunmen
description: French paramilitary commandos stormed a hijacked airliner tonight at Marseilles airport, freeing some 170 hostages and killing the four Islamic militant gunmen who had seized the plane at Algiers airport 54 hours earlier.

title: Music Returns to Haiti With the Spirit of Hope
description: For two months now, ever since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide returned from exile, one particular song has been playing everywhere in Haiti: on the radio, in the dance clubs, on the streets, in the fields. Called "Reconciliation," it has become a symbol of the mood of hopefulness that now prevails here.

title: OPEC Rivals Curb Cartel's Impact
description: The oil production of non-OPEC nations, declining since 1988, has begun an unexpected revival this year that will continue into the next century, tempering price increases and limiting the world's dependence on the oil cartel.

title: Communists In Germany Seek to Oust Hard-Liners
description: Leaders of the reformed Communist Party that ruled East Germany for 40 years will seek to oust hard-liners at a convention in January in the hope of breaking into the German political mainstream.

title: Legal Aid Meets City Hall
description: Just two months ago, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the Legal Aid Society, which provides lawyers for criminal defendants who cannot afford attorneys, were engaged in poisonous public combat. Lawyers who worked for the society then went out on strike, creating momentary chaos in the city's high-volume criminal justice system. The Mayor promptly clobbered the society, threatening to cancel its contract with the city and fire its lawyers. That forced the attorneys back to work.

title: John T. Dugan, 74, Writer and Professor
description: John T. Dugan, a freelance writer for the motion-picture and television industry in Los Angeles and former professor of drama, died on Saturday at his home in Encino, Calif. He was 74.

title: Back to Class Warfare
description: According to the wisdom of the new right, you and I are out of touch. People who peruse newspaper editorials rather than listen to bluster radio form part of a cultural elite that doesn't understand the hopes and hates of ordinary Americans. It isn't just those crocodile tears we shed for the undeserving poor or our prissy insistence on separating church and state that puts us out of touch: our very existence is offensive and threatening.

title: Criminals For Freedom
description: From concentration camps come few dispatches, not even when a whole nation is imprisoned. Silence is as real as barbed wire. For the captors, it is at least as effective.

title: In the Shadow of Stealth Bombers, a Missouri Hamlet Booms
description: Most towns with military installations are bracing for next year's large round of base closings and the economic calamity that they fear will follow. But not this tiny town, home to Whiteman Air Force Base.

title: The Good, Bad and In-Between In a Year of Surprises on Film
description: Flukes set the standard for 1994 on screen. While big films ("Wyatt Earp") and even big seasons (Christmas) fizzled, the triumphs came out of extreme left field. Foreign films were in serious decline, but American independent cinema experienced a burst of creative fervor. And, of course, Gump happened. More about that in a moment.

title: Alexandria, and in Just One Volume
description: OUT OF EGYPT A Memoir By Andre Aciman 340 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $20.

title: Nets Fall in Underachievers' Special
description: Armon Gilliam may have had the best take on the Nets' loss to the Milwaukee Bucks tonight when he was asked whether the Bucks were underrated.

title: From a Tiny Flaw, a Major Lesson
description: WHEN Macintosh users count their blessings for 1994, many will rejoice that they are counting them on a Power PC microprocessor instead of a Pentium chip.

title: Battle Over a Baby's Future Raises Hard Ethical Issues
description: Ryan Nguyen was born on Oct. 27, six weeks before his due date, asphyxiated and with barely a heartbeat. His doctors at Sacred Heart Medical Center in Spokane, Wash., revived him after heroic efforts. But a few weeks later, they decided that aggressive medical care would only prolong his suffering and that he would never survive infancy. They suggested that his life support be withdrawn.

title: Israel Offers a Good Alternative to Orphanages
description: To the Editor:

title: New Theory Would Reconcile Rival Views on Dinosaurs' Demise
description: IN the last decade or so two main schools of thought have clashed furiously over the question of what did in the dinosaurs. One school holds that a massive object from outer space slammed into the Earth, kicking up a worldwide pall of dust that blotted out the Sun and killed off many plants and animals. The other school prefers to seek the cause of the global mayhem in natural processes like big volcanic eruptions.

title: FIGGIE IN DEALS TO SELL ITS PACKAGING BUSINESSES
description: Figgie International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its packaging systems companies to Sasib S.p.A. of Italy and an American unit of Barry Wehmiller International P.L.C. of Britain. Terms were not disclosed. The deals, part of Figgie's effort to streamline operations and reduce debt, would remove the Willoughby, Ohio, company from the packaging business. Figgie said it had signed a agreement to sell its Geo. J. Meyer bottling machinery operations in Charleston, S.C., to Sasib, which would also buy a Figgie unit in Italy. Figgie also signed a letter of intent to sell its Akron, Ohio, manufacturing operation to the Barry Wehmiller Company of St. Louis.

title:
Real Estate;
A German bank will be the first new tenant for the new owner of the I.B.M. building in Manhattan.
description: THE developer Edward J. Minskoff, who is the new owner of the I.B.M. building at 590 Madison Avenue at 57th Street, has concluded a deal with BHF-Bank, a German bank that will be his first new tenant.

title: Woman in the News; A Disciplinarian to Shepherd Pataki's Budget: Patricia Ann Woodworth
description: When Patricia A. Woodworth was recruited as Michigan's budget director in 1991, she inherited a deficit equal to nearly 25 percent of the state budget as well as a history of Federal mandates and state court decisions that left little leeway to reduce spending. She immediately took aim at Michigan's welfare program and aggressively lobbied the Legislature to scrap relief for employable single adults -- a goal that skeptics figured she could not accomplish.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball Japan League

title: Coleman Still Hurting, And So Are the Nets
description: The 12 stitches came off Derrick Coleman's left hand tonight, but the Nets' power forward still did not touch a basketball. He sat on the bench in his double-breasted suit and watched his teammates succumb to the Knicks.

title: Rabin Visits Oman, Taking Step To Widen Link to Gulf Region
description: After flying secretly to Oman on Monday, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin returned publicly to Israel today, saying he hoped his visit, the first known trip by an Israeli leader to the Persian Gulf, would lead to wider ties with Arab and Muslim countries.

title: Market Place; A small specialty foods company moves to revitalize some longtime brands.
description: REMEMBER the slogan, "You don't have to be Jewish to love Levy's"? Well, you don't have to be kosher to go for a company whose ticker symbol is NOSH.

title: A Magic Mushroom Or a Toxic Fad?
description: IN cupboards and closets across the country, Kombucha mushrooms are floating in bowls of sugared tea and saturating a growing number of homes with the smell of vinegar and the hope for restored vigor.

title: Miscalculation in Chechnya
description: President Boris Yeltsin was justified in using force against the breakaway Russian republic of Chechnya, but as a political exercise and military operation the attack has been inept. That is now a problem for him and for Washington.

title: To Get Instant Flavor, Add Herbes de Provence
description: YEARS ago, when Julia Child began to teach Americans about French cooking, serious cooks learned about a mixture of herbs called herbes de Provence -- the herbs used often in the cooking of the Provence region of France that include rosemary, bay leaf and thyme. Now that fresh herbs are easy to find in this country, dried herbes de Provence are less popular. But they are a good standby for adding a lot of flavor very quickly. In today's menu, they are sprinkled on brussels sprouts before steaming.

title: FEDERATED SELLING TWO STORES TO SEARS
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it was selling the leases to two New York metropolitan area stores -- one Abraham & Straus outlet and one Stern's outlet -- to Sears, Roebuck & Company. Federated, which operates Bloomingdale's, Macy's, Stern's, Abraham & Straus and six other chains, said it was selling Sears its Stern's in the Sunrise mall in Massapequa, L.I., effective April 1; Sears will assume possession of the A & S store in Woodbridge, N.J., on Feb. 28. Sears expects to open its two new stores in about six months, after extensive remodeling. Federated also said it would convert the A & S store in the Sunrise mall to a Stern's to replace the one sold to Sears.

title: U.P.I. Talks With AT&T
description: United Press International, the privately held news wire service, said it was in talks with the AT&T Corporation to form a venture, possibly to provide on-line information services.

title: Notes of Nuttiness Instrumental to P. D. Q. Bach
description: As a musical stylist, P. D. Q. Bach may have been all over the place (or nowhere at all, depending on one's perspective), yet at the end of his "Short-Tempered Clavier," which Peter Schickele unveiled on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall, something suspiciously like a stylistic hallmark peeked through the clutter. The work's finale is a tribute to P. D. Q.'s purported father, Johann Sebastian Bach, and therefore used the dark, chromatic four-note motif that J. S. used as a musical signature. Who else but P. D. Q. Bach would introduce a rambunctious version of "He's a Jolly Good Fellow" as a counter theme?

title: IBERIA'S PILOTS CALL OFF A PLANNED STRIKE
description: Pilots at Iberia, the Spanish airline, called off a strike scheduled to start today after reaching an agreement last night with management on wage cuts and layoffs, state television reported. Under the agreement, pilots would accept cuts of as much as 15 percent of their salaries and the voluntary retirement of 150 of their 1,800 members, Television Espanola said. The cuts are contingent upon management's agreeing to include the pilots' proposals for the airline in a cost-cutting plan presented to the European Union. Iberia seeks European Union approval for a 130 billion peseta ($977 million) Government subsidy. Iberia last year had a loss of 69 billion pesetas.

title: The Fine Art of Words That Echo and Re-Echo
description: "YO, oy," we said in greeting and lamentation, hoping to impress Jon Agee, the palindromist, whom we were meeting for the first time at lunch.

title: Asian Workers Lift Themselves by Bootstraps; A Job for Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Broadcasting Doesn't Need Fixing
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Prosecutors Win Court Supervision of Union Once Controlled by Mob
description: The Federal Government yesterday succeeded in gaining tight control of a New York City union representing construction laborers, a union that prosecutors contended was dominated and repeatedly plundered by organized crime.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The weather may be balmy for December in New York, but nevermind. Coats are all that are on the mind of ED ABRAHAMS, director of the sixth annual New York Cares Coat Drive.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: BUDGET POST GOES TO MICHIGAN OFFICIAL

title: Jefferson of Chargers Is Arrested
description: The San Diego Chargers receiver SHAWN JEFFERSON was jailed briefly yesterday in Alpine, Calif., after being arrested for investigation of drunken driving and gun violations.

title: More Youths in U.S. End Up Behind Bars
description: While many experts say prisonlike juvenile institutions do more harm than good, the number of teen-agers sent to them nationwide rose to more than 90,000 in 1991, from 70,000 in 1979. The numbers are likely to rise even faster in the next few years, as calls for tougher punishment grow, new prisons are built and states continue to send youths involved in serious crimes to adult courts and prisons. A special report, When Trouble Starts Young, turns today to questions of punishment and deterrence.

title: Families Deserve Nursing-Home Option
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Readies China Tariffs
description: The Clinton Administration expects to name on Friday at least $800 million in Chinese products that could face trade sanctions because of China's failure to curb unauthorized copying of American products, officials said today.

title: PLAINS SPIRIT STOCK UP ON MERCANTILE BANCORP OFFER
description: Shares of the Plains Spirit Financial Corporation rose 28 percent yesterday on news that Mercantile Bancorp had agreed to buy First Federal Savings Bank of Iowa for $64 million in stock and cash. Plains Spirit is the parent of First Federal, which has assets of $428 million. Mercantile, of St. Louis, said it would issue 1.4 million shares, worth about $44.5 million based on Friday's closing price of $31.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. The rest of the deal would be in cash. Plains Spirit shares rose $6.25, to $28.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Pentium and Our Crisis of Faith
description: During the Middle Ages, the world held its breath while theologians argued over how many angels occupied the heads of pins. Today, the pinheads are made of silicon, and humanity was made to hold what little breath it has left while the articles of faith were rewritten by a computer chip that has a tough time with 16-digit division.

title:
HORSE RACING;
Jockeys Are Negotiating With Individual Tracks
description: The Jockeys' Guild, unable to come to terms with the Thoroughbred Racing Associations over insurance coverage for jockeys, is negotiating individually with several T.R.A.-member tracks in an attempt to keep regular riders in action on Jan. 1.

title: Even With Guilty Plea, Justice Official's Crimes and Motives Remain Enigma
description: Early last month, Webster L. Hubbell traveled to Arkansas to tell a few old friends that the embezzlement charges he had denied so vehemently for so long were actually true.

title: It's Official: Texans Outnumber New Yorkers
description: Population estimates for 1994 issued by the Census Bureau today showed that Texas has surpassed New York as the second-most-populous state as a result of fewer people moving to the Empire State from other parts of the country.

title: Wine Talk
description: AMERICANS, we are told, drink Champagne only on holidays and special occasions, while Europeans drink it all year long. Perhaps the Europeans are just better at dreaming up special occasions.

title: MICHIGAN OFFICIAL NAMED BY PATAKI AS BUDGET CHIEF
description: Five days before his inauguration, Governor-elect George E. Pataki reached beyond his small circle of confidants yesterday and named as budget director the chief fiscal officer in Michigan, a state that national Republicans consider at the forefront of their effort to rein in government.

title: The Jets: Still Looking for Winning Formula
description: All anyone will remember about the 1994 Jets was that they blew it again. There they were, the last Sunday in November, 22 seconds from tying for first place in the division, but then losing to the Dolphins. They finished with five straight losses and a 6-10 season.

title: Asian Workers Lift Themselves by Bootstraps; Meanwhile at Mattel
description: To the Editor:

title:
AT LUNCH WITH DARRYL JONES;
Complete Unknown And Rolling Stone
description: THE new bass guitar player for the Rolling Stones is sitting in a sushi bar here talking about automobiles.

title: Brazilian Way With Mornings After
description: EVER since Plato asked the question "How can we drink with least injury to ourselves?" nearly every culture has devised its own answers.

title: With Bosnia Quiet, U.N. Pushes for More Lasting Cease-Fire
description: Fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina has all but stopped after a seven-day cease-fire negotiated last week by former President Jimmy Carter.

title: Advanced Placement Exams Suffering an Erosion in Value
description: For more than 40 years, Advanced Placement tests have been a standard fixture in high school for America's ablest students. While they attended high school, the students earned college credit by taking demanding classes from art and Latin to calculus and physics.

title: People
description: * Dan Krumwiede was named executive vice president and chief creative officer at Miller Meester Advertising, Minneapolis, succeeding Doug Engel, who was named to the new position of executive vice president and management supervisor for food and consumer accounts. Mr. Krumwiede previously headed his own agency, Krumwiede & Associates, Minneapolis, which is closing. * Terri Burke and Alan M. Reisberg were named to the new positions of executive vice presidents and account directors at Trahan, Burden & Charles, Baltimore. Ms. Burke was previously a senior vice president and account director at Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., and Mr. Reisberg was previously marketing communications director at Dell Computer Corp., Austin, Tex.

title: Players and Owners File Complaints With Labor Board
description: Unable to settle their duel over baseball's economic system at the bargaining table, striking players and owners filed dual unfair-labor-practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: With Each Fall in Peso, Tourism Bargains Rise
description: While the devaluation of the peso has caused an exodus of investment dollars from Mexico, travel agents say American tourists will be going in the opposite direction, heading to Mexico, where the dollar will now buy much more.

title: Food Notes
description: Salmon That Bites Back

title: No Headline
description: "I think that cutting taxes is very doable in New York." -- PATRICIA A. WOODWORTH, the state's new budget director. [ B4:5. ]

title: Who Will Clean Up The Ticket Scandal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Prospects for Children
description: There is encouraging news, at last, from the United Nations Children's Fund, which annually assesses the state of the world's children.

title: Wine for the Heart: Over All, Risks May Outweigh Benefits
description: ALCOHOL consumption rises precipitously in this holiday season, but before you raise yet another glass to everyone's health, take heed of these new findings based on data from 21 affluent countries: while wine and other forms of alcohol may protect your heart, when consumed in large amounts alcohol does nothing to prolong your life.

title: Hard Time for Hard Youths: A Battle Producing Few Winners
description: When Shahid S. was strutting around Newark with an automatic pistol jammed into his waistband, stealing cars, selling drugs and mugging people, he would sometimes hear older boys talking about the prison where New Jersey sends its most incorrigible teen-agers.

title: Public-TV Offshoot Finds That the Fringe Is a Risky Place to Be
description: In the next two months, about 150 television stations across America plan to broadcast the offbeat film series "TV Families." This seven-part series is filled with surprises. Todd Haynes's "Dottie Gets Spanked" presents the protosexual fantasies of a 6-year-old boy obsessed with a sitcom actress. The anarchic Japanese family in Jon Moritsugu's "Terminal U.S.A." moves into territory well beyond Al Bundy. In Tamara Jenkins's "Family Remains," a young woman opens her front door and discovers that her long-lost father has been delivered in a coffin.

title: Nevada Medical Board Approves Holyfield
description: The two-time heavyweight champion EVANDER HOLYFIELD will get to fight in Nevada again if the state athletic commission accepts the recommendation of its medical advisory board.

title: Eating in 1994: The Year Beef Came Back
description: Fat is up, but so is low fat. Organic foods are growing; pretzels are, too. When it comes to vegetables, iceberg lettuce is still a favorite.

title: Mitsubishi-Asahi Glass
description: A joint venture owned by the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and the Asahi Glass Company will spend $400 million to build a plant for production of color liquid crystal display panels, Mitsubishi said today.

title: MEXICAN CURRENCY RESUMES ITS FALL, OFFICIALS SILENT
description: Mexico's economic crisis took a new turn for the worse today as investors dumped more of their holdings in pesos, driving the value of the Mexican currency down by nearly 10 percent more against the dollar.

title: Ryan Plans Changes for the Cardinals
description: BUDDY RYAN shed some light yesterday on how he intends to improve his team's offense.

title: Personal Health
description: BY the age of 3, virtually every American child has had at least one respiratory infection caused by a virus that few people have heard of and fewer still take seriously. It is respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., which was first discovered in chimpanzees in 1956 but was soon recognized as a nearly universal cause of a cold-like illness in people.

title: Of Epic Hangovers And Hairs of Dogs
description: A CHILI pepper, a hunk of bread, some bacon fat, a shot of brandy. This may not be a standard breakfast menu, but if it's midafternoon on the day after the big night and the ceiling above the bed looks like a jumbled jigsaw puzzle, it might be just what's in order.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIED SIGNAL INC., Morristown, N.J., said a unit, Allied Signal Technical Services, was awarded a $31.6 million contract by Taiwan's space agency to develop and install the ground system for its satellite program.

title: Mexico Fund
description: Shares of the Mexico Fund, a closed-end mutual fund that invests in Mexican securities, fell for the eighth consecutive session yesterday. It set a 52-week low of $19.625, before closing at $20. The fund began tumbling just before the Dec. 20 devaluation of the peso.

title: 21 Injured in 2 Separate Manhattan Fires
description: Twenty-one people were hurt in two fires in Manhattan early yesterday, including 16 firefighters injured when a gas explosion sent a fireball surging through a restaurant where they had finished fighting a kitchen blaze, officials said.

title: Doctors Call Oakley's Surgery a Success
description: The surgery performed on Charles Oakley's dislocated right toe today was termed a success by his physicians, meaning that the Knicks' power forward is expected to return to action in around eight weeks.

title: F.C.C. Speeds Up Auction
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would speed auctions of wireless phone licenses for small companies that want a part of the new personal communications services market.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEFFREY ARCHER, the best-selling novelist, was injured with his wife when their car plummeted down a highway embankment near London yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Salmon and Stuffed Eggs: A Light Duo
description: THIS menu is deliberately light. The holiday parties and feasts of December provide so much opportunity to indulge that I find it a relief to eat light dishes at home whenever possible at this time of year. Delicate salmon fills the bill perfectly.

title: Milton Pitts, 82, Favorite Barber Of Four Presidents
description: Milton Pitts, the barber who prompted President Richard M. Nixon to set up a White House barbershop and who cut the hair of three other Republican presidents as well as other celebrities, died on Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 82 and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Head-On Collision Kills 4 Teen-Agers and an Adult
description: The parking lot at Brewster High School was almost full today, despite the vacation, as more than 100 students gathered to comfort each other and receive counseling after four of their friends and a former Sunday school teacher were killed in a head-on collision here on Monday.

title: Accounts
description: * Stone Products Corp., Napa, Calif., to Hayes Orlie Cundall, Sausalito, Calif., to handle advertising for the manufacturer of building products, previously handled in-house. The billings were estimated to exceed $1 million. * Medicine-on-Time, Baltimore, to the Reeves Agency, Baltimore, to handle consumer and trade advertising for the manufacturer of multiple-dose prescription packaging, previously handled by Eisner & Associates, Baltimore. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Miscellany
description: * Fotouhi Alonso Advertising and Marketing, Century City, Calif., has been renamed Fotouhi Alonso Agnew Advertising and Marketing, to reflect the contributions of Jim Agnew, partner and president. * Ken Williams and David Landau have opened Multiverse Networks, New York and Los Angeles, a national advertising sales representation and affiliate relations management company for the radio industry. Mr. Williams, former vice president and managing director at Media America Inc., Los Angeles, becomes chairman, based in the Los Angeles office. Mr. Landau, former senior vice president at Global Marketing, New York, becomes president and chief executive in the New York office.

title: Local Group Makes Offer for Buccaneers
description: A local group made an offer to buy the Tampa Bay Buccaneers that is valid until Jan. 9, a trustee for the team said yesterday.

title: Martin Marietta Settlement
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation will pay almost $5.9 million to settle a lawsuit contending that its radar division, under earlier ownership by the General Electric Company, made improper payments to win an Egyptian Government contract.

title: Changing a City Where Driving Seems Competitive
description: No one knows exactly when, but sometime in the last several years defensive driving took on new meaning in this hub of frantic Fairfield County commuting.

title: Piper Jaffray Fails to Get Delay in Suit
description: Piper Jaffray Inc. has lost its bid to delay a lawsuit about declines related to derivatives in its Institutional Government Income Fund.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 22 about a legal decision supporting President Clinton's timber-cutting program for the Northwest misstated the year Mr. Clinton led a public meeting in an effort to resolve the differences between conservationists and loggers. It was 1993.

title: Allie Reynolds, Star Pitcher For Yankees, Is Dead at 79
description: Allie Reynolds, a pitcher Manager Casey Stengel once called "two ways great" because of his skills as a starter and a reliever for six New York Yankee World Series champions from 1947 through 1953, died yesterday in Oklahoma City. He was 79.

title: Russia's New Budget Raises Doubt on a Stable Economy
description: After 13 votes over three days last week, the Russian Parliament finally approved the first reading of a tight 1995 budget. But the real battle over spending limits is still to take place, the Russian military action in Chechnya could bust the budget and the Government has brought Western aid into question by reneging on promises to remove controls on domestic energy prices.

title: Whipping Post: Struggling Knicks Bully the Nets
description: It was not a masterpiece, but the Knicks recaptured the art of winning tonight.

title: Karl Schiller, 83, Ex-Minister Of Economics in West Germany
description: Karl Schiller, a former government minister who dominated West German economic and financial policy in the late 1960's and early 70's, died in a hospital in Hamburg on Monday. He was 83.

title: ITT Moves To Shed More Units
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had sold one of its consumer finance companies to the Norwest Corporation and that it was close to selling three more financial services subsidiaries to an unidentified buyer.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE FOOTBALL Utah Just Wriggles Past Arizona

title: Families Deserve Nursing-Home Option; Support Group
description: To the Editor:

title: World Court Could Outlaw Nuclear Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Prices Advance Despite Bond Worries
description: The stock market rose yesterday in light trading, despite a bond market that may spell bad news for stocks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7 MEXICAN PESO PLUNGES Mexico's economic crisis worsened, as the peso plunged nearly 10 percent more against the dollar and stocks fell. Meanwhile, the Mexican Government gave no indication of its economic strategy. A1

title: Delta Air Lines to Pay Debt
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that it planned to use the $145 million in proceeds from a legal victory against the defunct Pam Am Corporation to pay off debt.

title: Zurich Insurance Will Control Home Holdings
description: Home Holdings, an American insurer plagued by losses and declining ratings, will be transferred by its Swedish parent to the control of the Zurich Insurance Group, the three companies announced yesterday.

title: The Bears, Ahem, Are Very Tough
description: Since taking over as Vikings coach, Dennis Green has never lost to the Bears. The Vikings are 6-0 against Chicago, including two victories this season in which they outscored the Bears by 75-41.

title: INSIDE
description: Enigma of an Official's Fall

title: Sheffer Breathes Life Into Huskies
description: Connecticut won again tonight, bringing its record to 6-0, by playing the kind of pressing defense so pleasing to Coach Jim Calhoun.

title: Erickson Finally Answers Question: He's Staying
description: This is no time for clouds, not at the Orange Bowl, where the University of Miami will have an opportunity to re-establish a reputation as a force that seemed lost a year ago. The meeting with Nebraska on Sunday night may hold little realistic hope of a national championship, but its impact on the future still makes it one of the most important moments in Dennis Erickson's coaching career.

title: Merchants Fear Fewer Sales Ahead
description: Even as retailers take final markdowns as they prepare to bring in new merchandise, they worry that 1995 is shaping up as a difficult year.

title: Apartheid's Gone, and Anything Goes
description: After growing up an exile in Europe and America, Dali Tambo returned to South Africa in 1990 to discover that apartheid was only part of the story. Along with white political supremacy came an official code of sexual behavior rooted in conservative Afrikaner Christianity.

title: Pauline Kael, Loving and Loathing
description: FOR KEEPS By Pauline Kael 1,291 pages. A William Abrahams Book/Dutton. $34.95.

title: Debating the Extra Year: One Child's Stepping Stone Is Another's Stigma
description: Among many teachers and parents active in programs that give children an extra year to prepare for first grade, there is the belief that the programs greatly benefit the children later in life. The advocates feel they have given such children a chance to grow up a little at their own pace.

title: Sports of The Times; Team Man, From Head To Toe
description: IT is strangely ironic that Charles Oakley was in the operating room at Beth Israel Hospital yesterday because he couldn't pull off a Mark Messier-like power play back in October, couldn't put himself before his team.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK TO TAKE A $195 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said yesterday it would take a charge of $195 million, or 89 cents a share, in the fourth quarter related to previously announced job cuts. The cuts will save the Syracuse company about $60 million in operating costs for 1995 alone, which will be used to trim its electric and natural-gas rate requests. Including the latest cuts, Niagara Mohawk said it will have reduced staff by more than 3,100 employees since early 1993.

title: Dolphins' Bowens Gets Rookie Honors
description: TIM BOWENS, a player some National Football League general managers and scouts regarded as a long shot, was selected yesterday as the 1994 Associated Press Defensive Rookie of the Year.

title: A Palestinian-Settler Duel: Olive Trees vs. Bulldozers
description: The Palestinians planted tiny olive trees; the Israeli soldiers dug them up. The Palestinians lay down in the road to block a bulldozer; the Israelis carted them off to police vans. The Palestinians attacked the soldiers; the Israeli troops fought back.

title: Drug Accusations Swirl After Killing of Minister
description: The Baltimore County Police said today that they were investigating whether the killing of a minister here on Christmas Eve involved a robbery, drug use by the victim and suspect or both.

title: Man Indicted In Bombing On Subway
description: Edward J. Leary was indicted yesterday on charges of carrying the firebomb that injured more than 40 people on a crowded subway on Dec. 21 as part of an extortion plot to hold the city's subways ransom.

title: Siemens in South Africa
description: Siemens A.G. has an order from South Africa's national telecommunications carrier for a new high-speed data network as well as expansion of its existing metropolitan area network, Siemens said. Siemens did not disclose the value of the order from Telkom S.A. A spokesman, Christof Bachmair, said only that the order totalled in the "two digit millions" of German marks.

title: Name Changes Rose In 1994, Survey Says
description: The number of corporate name changes rose again in 1994, according to an annual survey, primarily because of corporate revamping and marketplace competition.

title: Vancouver Journal; Planet Earth's Preacher, With Canada His Pulpit
description: He recycles like mad to cut his family's garbage down to one bag a month, uses refillable fountain pens, cloth handkerchiefs and reusable chopsticks, and gets around on buses, bikes and skates.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Rite Aid to Buy Michigan Drug Chain
description: Continuing its aggressive expansion, the Rite Aid Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Perry Drug Stores Inc., Michigan's largest drugstore chain, for $132 million in cash, or $11 a share.

title: As Toll Rises in Algeria's War, a Dearth of News
description: The world's press has been largely shut out of the Algerian civil war, which has claimed 600 to 1,000 victims each month since this summer.

title: Paying Tribute to Those Who Taught the Meaning of Giving
description: They escaped to the United States from Nazi Germany, and afterward, Ruth Marton and her sister, Gerd Muehsam, always felt grateful for their comfortable life here. So when Mrs. Muehsam died in 1979, Mrs. Marton started donating $100 a year to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in her memory.

title: Eating in 1994: The Year Beef Came Back
description: THE news may be startling to Americans who live in pockets of gastronomic enlightenment, but 1994 may be remembered as the year when beef came back, when sweets and snacks in low-fat versions were consumed in record numbers and when the nation looked at vegetables and collectively said, "I say it's spinach and I say the hell with it."

title: He Disarmed A Gunman But Insists He's No Hero
description: The rifle was pointed inches from Jason McEnaney's chest and he knew he had to act.

title: I.R.S. Wants to Charge $43 For Installment Payments
description: The Internal Revenue Service proposed today to make it just a little bit harder on millions of financially struggling taxpayers by charging them $43 for the privilege of paying in installments.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a couple looking at the Washington Monument referred incorrectly in some copies to the water between the monument and the Lincoln Memorial. It is the Reflecting Pool, not the Reflecting Pond.

title: Beverly Buys Big Workers Comp Dealer
description: Beverly Enterprises Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Pharmacy Management Services Inc. in a stock swap valued at $148.5 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about the sale of the ITT Corporation's commercial finance unit to the Deutsche Bank of Germany, misstated the financial terms of the deal. ITT said yesterday that the total purchase price was about $2.3 billion but that the company had agreed to assume about $1.4 billion of the subsidiary's debt payments, lowering the net gain for ITT to approximately $900 million. A related article appears on page D1.

title: For McCann-Erickson New York, a push to revitalize creativity.
description: AT the offices of McCann-Erickson New York, the arrival of a brightly painted popcorn machine, the type once found along carnival midways and beach boardwalks, says a lot about how the large and successful, yet stolid and stodgy, agency is remaking itself.

title: Going Mad Without Being a Sore Loser
description: All the world's a stage for King George III, the royally irrepressible ruler who holds sway throughout "The Madness of King George." While there's much to admire in Nicholas Hytner's splendid screen adaptation of Alan Bennett's neo-Shakespearean play ("The Madness of George III"), this exuberant tragicomedy is first and foremost a superb showcase. The monarch is a corker, and he commands almost all the attention.

title: Prostitutes Defy Killer by Working
description: On a side street of the commercial strip known as the Tamiami Trail, business was brisk for three prostitutes on a recent late night, even under new rules: the two women and the male transvestite would work only in parked cars within screaming distance of the others.

title: Chaos Presides in New York Housing Courts
description: On Johnny L. Baynes's first day as a tenants' lawyer in Brooklyn housing court in 1984, he thought he would lose his mind. The halls were jammed with people clutching eviction notices and the volume was headache-inducing: babies wailing, court officers yelling out cases, and landlords' lawyers and tenants negotiating rents in full cry in the stairwells.

title: Greening New York's Waste Lands
description: New York City is dotted with waste lands that are homes to nothing but generations of garbage and generations of rats. The city itself owns nearly 20,000 such vacant lots, acquired after their owners defaulted on taxes. The city would love to sell them, but they are hardly hot properties at the moment -- except, the Giuliani administration hopes, to companies looking for a literally grass-roots way to promote their products.

title: Police Say Hijackers Planned to Blow Up Jet Over Paris
description: The French Government said today that it ordered paramilitary commandos to storm a hijacked Air France airliner at Marseilles airport Monday after learning that the Islamic militant gunmen who took over the plane in Algiers were planning to blow it up over Paris.

title: U.S. Warning North Koreans On Atom Deal
description: The United States has warned North Korea that its failure to release a captured American pilot could jeopardize the recently negotiated nuclear agreement between the two countries, senior Administration officials said today.

title: A Rare Mix of Tenants; Working Residents Create a New Model for Welfare Hotels
description: In the ornate lobby of the former Times Square Hotel, a remarkable cross-section of people come and go.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline as Nasdaq Prices Fall
description: The number of shares borrowed and sold short but not covered declined to 777.4 million, from 802.2 million in November. Short interest peaked in August, at 849.2 million shares, and is now at its lowest level since June.

title: PROCYTE REJECTS SCHERER-DERMA SCIENCES OFFER
description: The Procyte Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected an unsolicited buyout offer from Scherer Healthcare Inc. and Derma Sciences Inc., which have agreed to merge. Procyte said it viewed the offer by the companies as an attempt by Scherer "to finance the current operations and future growth of its money-losing holdings." Scherer officials could not be reached to comment. The Scherer-Derma offer called for Scherer to exchange one share for 3.4 shares of Procyte. At the same time, Scherer would exchange one share for every 4.1 Derma shares.

title: No Problems for Penn in Spotlight
description: The University of Pennsylvania has the highest winning percentage among Division I basketball programs over the past two seasons (.855).

title: Cordial Visit to Mansion And Some Mixed Feelings
description: Setting in motion Albany's first changing of the guard in 12 years, Matilda Raffa Cuomo gave Libby R. Pataki her first tour of the Executive Mansion today, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo bade farewell to a Capitol press corps that he had alternately charmed and chided during his years in office.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The high price of separation: the PRINCE and PRINCESS OF WALES are paying one more penalty for their marital split. They both wanted to join the Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla., which is owned by DONALD TRUMP, so each had to pay the $50,000 initiation fee. Ordinarily, a single membership covers the member's spouse and children as well.

title: The Giants: A Good Finish May Bode Well for Next Season
description: This was one of the strangest seasons the Giants have seen in recent years. They won three straight games, lost seven straight, then finished with six consecutive victories. There were quarterback benchings, rumors that Coach Dan Reeves might leave, as well as public squabbles between Reeves and General Manager George Young.

title: A Banner Year for One Farmer
description: After long days of doctoring the soil and fighting weeds and insects, after the machinery is parked for the winter and the harvest stored or sold, a year on David Rothermel's farm comes down to this: a bewildering stack of computer printouts and accounting reports on the family-room table.

title: High-Tech Death From Alabama
description: The United States is already the most murderous nation in the Western world. The last thing it needs is a more efficient way to commit homicide. The Olin Corporation's Winchester Ammunition Division acted responsibly last year when it withdrew from the market a destructive, razor-fingered bullet known as the "Black Talon," which grinds up internal organs and threatens surgeons who try to remove it. But the Signature Products Corporation of Huntsville, Ala., has stepped into the breach and is seeking Government permission to market two new bullets that, if Signature's claims are true, are just as destructive. They should be banned.

title: Book Notes
description: Small and Selective

title: Prices Rise For Bonds in Thin Trading
description: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, and the yield on the 30-year bond fell to a three-month low in thin holiday trading.

title: 21 Hurt in Fires
description: Twenty-one people were hurt in two fires in Manhattan, including 16 firefighters injured in a gas explosion at a restaurant where they had fought a kitchen blaze, officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about the best films of 1994 misstated the medium for which "The Last Seduction" was produced. It was made for theatrical release, but the broadcast rights were acquired by Home Box Office, which showed it on cable television starting in July. Its United States theatrical premiere was in October.

title: Ronald Haft Files Motion Against Dart
description: Lawyers for Ronald S. Haft, the president of the Dart Group Corporation, filed a contempt motion today against Dart and three of its directors, including his father.

title: PERSEPTIVE BIOSYSTEMS DISCLOSES ACCOUNTING ERRORS
description: Stock in Perseptive Biosystems Inc. fell 35.7 percent yesterday after the company said it overstated revenues in past financial statements. Perseptive, a Cambridge, Mass., maker of laboratory equipment, said it had improperly recognized revenue since fiscal 1993. According to corrected calculations, the company's net loss for the nine months ended June 30 widened to $13.1 million from the $5.6 million previously reported. Revenue fell to $28.3 million from the $38.4 million previously reported. The company also said that Robert Fein, a senior vice president, would no longer serve as its chief financial officer. Company shares dropped $2.50, to $4.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Some Progress Is Seen From Japan Trade Talks
description: Negotiators from the United States and Japan appeared to make progress today toward resolving a deadlock over the sale of American automobiles and auto parts in Japan, one of the most contentious issues in the strained trade relations between the nations.

title: Chevron's Angola Fields
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that its Angola subsidiary found four new offshore oil fields during 1994. Chevron said production from its Angola concession averaged a record 320,000 daily barrels in the year, and would rise to 390,000 barrels a day next year as the company continues to develop deep-water areas. Chevron holds a 39 percent interest in the Angola concession through its affiliate, the Cabinda Gulf Oil Company.

title: Krumrie Becomes Bengal Line Coach
description: The Cincinnati Bengals added TIM KRUMRIE to the coaching staff yesterday as a defensive line assistant, hoping that the enthusiasm he showed during his 12-year career as a nose tackle will rub off on the rest of the team. (AP)

title: Man in the News; Turning Loss Into Victory: Daniel Robert Glickman
description: Representative Dan Glickman of Kansas, President Clinton's choice to become Secretary of Agriculture, may yet prove that it is possible to win by losing.

title: In America; The Sweatshop Lives
description: A form of industrial exploitation that had been concealed from most Americans literally burst into the open with the 1911 Triangle Shirtwaist Company fire in lower Manhattan, which killed 146 workers, mostly young women and girls.

title: Asian Workers Lift Themselves by Bootstraps
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO -- Expand or Die?
description: What should be Europe's and NATO's relationship with Russia? The question must be answered soon, and decisively, if the United States' historic commitment to Europe is to remain intact.

title: Unlocking Oil in Canada's Tar Sands
description: For millions of years, crude oil has been locked within the tar sands that abound along the Athabasca River, 300 miles north of Edmonton, but until recently it looked doubtful that the estimated 300 billion barrels could be recovered economically.

title: Glenn MacNary, 81, Retired President Of Baking Company
description: B. Glenn MacNary, a retired president and director of the Continental Baking Company, died on Sunday at Barnstable County Hospital in Bourne, Mass. A former resident of Manhasset and Rye, N.Y., Mr. MacNary was 81 and lived in North Falmouth, Mass.

title: Public Broadcasting Doesn't Need Fixing; Fighting Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighborhood Confrontation Is Captured By St. John's
description: A sellout crowd. Two unbeaten city teams. Felipe Lopez making his Madison Square Garden debut. There was little more the Chemical Bank ECAC Holiday Festival could expect for an opening-round matchup. But it got more: a thrilling basketball game that was played just the way you'd expect two unbeaten teams fighting over the neighborhood turf to play.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Yeltsin Limits Air Raids on the Chechen Capital
description: Facing growing public opposition to the war in secessionist Chechnya, President Boris N. Yeltsin said on television tonight that he intended to press forward to seize the rebel capital but that he had ordered a halt to the bombing of civilians there.

title: On Letting Dollars Fly Out the Window
description: To the Editor:

title: Clubs and Players Quiet As Arenas Are Quieter
description: On the 88th day of the hockey lockout, the two sides couldn't even agree on why they weren't negotiating.

title: The 1% Solution
description: When Newt Gingrich said he intended to "zero out" financing for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, he aimed in the wrong direction. Instead of attacking an impoverished service that has brought intellectual and cultural treasures to millions of viewers and listeners, he should focus on commercial TV and radio broadcasters.

title: From the Ivy League and Bay Ridge, Two of Pataki's Conservative Pillars
description: They are the odd couple of conservative politics. Thomas L. Rhodes has two Ivy League degrees and made millions on Wall Street. Michael R. Long skipped college to join the Marines and now runs a liquor store in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Southern Co.(SO,N) reports earnings for 12mos to Nov 30
description: Earnings for the 11 months and 12 months ended November 1994 reflected a $ 51 million charge and a $ 9 million charge for Georgia Power Company's and Southern Company Services' 1994 work force reduction programs, respectively.The 11 months' results are not reported.The share earnings and shares outstanding reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock distribution for each share held as of Feb. 7, 1994.Revenue represented operating revenues.

title: JAPANESE DEPARTMENT STORES TO FORM ALLIANCE
description: Mitsukoshi Ltd. and Daimaru Inc., two large Japanese department store companies, said yesterday that they had formed a merchandising alliance to increase their buying power and reduce costs. The companies plan to work together to produce private-label merchandise, buy branded goods and develop joint distribution and marketing and advertising programs. Although Mitsukoshi and Daimaru will remain separate companies, their goals in forming the alliance are similar to the goals of American retailers who are consolidating through mergers and acquisitions. With 14 stores in western Japan, Mitsukoshi has about $7.9 billion in sales. Daimaru, which operates seven stores in the eastern part of the country, has revenues of about $5.4 billion.

title: Economic Scene; From Kodak, two images of its competitive position.
description: AS far as the Eastman Kodak Company is concerned:

title: St. John's Needs to Counter Penn Savvy
description: There is one thing that can be counted on in tonight's championship game of the Chemical Bank ECAC Holiday Festival at Madison Square Garden: St. John's isn't going to outsmart the Penn Quakers. It has nothing to do with a Big East school playing an Ivy League opponent. It has everything to do with youth versus experience.

title: Wellcome's Anti-Epilepsy Drug Approved for U.S.
description: Wellcome P.L.C. has won approval to market two drugs in the United States, prompting speculation that the company may obtain further approvals from the Food and Drug Administration this week.

title: Adoption Saga Of Rio's Streets
description: As she stood in front of the Candelaria Church on a recent steel-gray afternoon, at the site of the 1993 murder of eight street children, tears welled in Jacquelyn Bracy's eyes. In August 1993, she learned of the plight of Rio's street children while watching a segment on ABC's "World News Tonight," at her home near Sacramento, Calif.

title: Bailout Plan For Mexico Wins Praise
description: Bankers and financial analysts gave a cautious welcome yesterday to reports that the United States was preparing a multibillion-dollar international aid package for Mexico. But they cautioned that any revival of confidence in Mexico's battered currency and economy would remain fragile for a long time to come.

title: Company Puts Hold on a Plastic Bullet
description: The maker of a new high-tech bullet that it says can pierce armored vests declared today that it would delay the bullet's manufacture after sharp criticism from police associations that criminals would gain access to it.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: A PATAKI APPOINTEE FOCUSES ON WELFARE

title: Padres and Astros Make a 12-Player Swap
description: Operating on the economic theory that a club has to spend money to make money, the new owner of the San Diego Padres reversed the free fall yesterday and restocked his team with some talent. In the biggest baseball deal in numbers in 37 years, the Padres made a 12-player trade with the Houston Astros, acquiring third baseman Ken Caminiti and center fielder Steve Finley in their group of six players.

title: No More Search-and-Seizure Loopholes
description: Political attacks on the exclusionary rule, which judges invoke to throw out illegally obtained evidence, are perennials. Many police officers, prosecutors and conservative politicians argue that the justice system unjustly sets the guilty free because of an officer's mistaken search or seizure.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday on a proposal to lease New York City's vacant lots to corporate sponsors misstated the number of community districts in the city. It is 59.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Visions of the Lower East Side
description: IMAGINE the Lower East Side as Jody Culkin did, with a pool running the length of Allen Street. Or Rutgers Street as Gilda Pervin envisioned it: a living-room piazza, above, with sofa and flower-bedecked rug.

title: A New Alliance To Aid Professionals
description: BPA International, an organization that audits the circulation of business and consumer publications, and the Business Marketing Association, an organization for business-to-business marketing professionals, are teaming to offer members educational and professional development programs.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS TO MARKET NEW ORAL MORPHINE DRUG
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company has acquired the exclusive rights to market a new oral morphine drug in the United States, the drug's developer said yesterday. Terms were not disclosed. F. H. Faulding & Company of Australia, the drug's manufacturer, said the drug used slow-release technology to provide relief for cancer patients and other people who suffer from chronic pain. Bristol-Myers, based in New York, will market the drug under the trademark Kadian. Faulding said its Purepac Inc. unit would manufacture the drug in the United States.

title: Umpires Will Be Locked Out
description: Major league umpires were notified yesterday that they will be locked out beginning next week. They don't have any games to umpire, so it is their salaries they will be locked out from receiving.

title: HANDLEMAN TO ACQUIRE LEVY MUSIC AND VIDEO
description: The Handleman Company, the nation's largest supplier of music, video, books and personal computer software to retail chains, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Levy Music and Video, a music and video supplier. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Levy Music and Video, a division of Levy Home Entertainment Inc. of Chicago, has annual sales of more than $50 million. Handleman, based in Troy, Mich., said the deal would probably be completed in early January.

title: Proponent of Work for Welfare Is Among 9 Pataki Appointments
description: Governor-elect George E. Pataki yesterday named Westchester's Commissioner for Social Services to do for the state what she has done at home -- dramatically reduce the cost of welfare. But unable to persuade Commissioner Mary E. Glass to sign on for the long term, he agreed to limit her appointment to 90 days.

title: Plan to Cut Program For Disabled Youths
description: As part of their effort to redesign welfare and control costs, House Republicans are drafting legislation to abolish a part of the Supplemental Security Income program that provides cash grants of up to $446 a month for children with severe disabilities like mental retardation, cerebral palsy and spina bifida. The program, which serves 847,000 children, would be replaced with vouchers that could be spent on a more limited program of medical care.

title: Life Evolving Through Nikolais's Prism
description: "The Crystal and the Sphere," a mixed-media dance piece that Alwin Nikolais created in 1990 shortly before his death, is one of the more imaginative holiday programs on show this week.

title: Heinz Chooses Langworth Pantel
description: The Heinz U.S.A. division of the H. J. Heinz Company has named the Langworth Pantel Group in White Plains to handle promotions for Heinz ketchup, Heinz 57 sauce and Heinz Home Style gravy. Billings were not disclosed. Langworth Pantel, which had handled the brands on a project basis since last December, was awarded the assignment after a six-month review that began with 60 agencies and was narrowed to Langworth Pantel and two or three other undisclosed finalists.

title: Accounts
description: * Khoper Invest, Moscow, to YAR Communications, New York and Moscow, to handle the financial services company's account in Russia, previously handled by various Russian agencies. Billings were estimated to exceed $20 million. * Management Recruiters International, Cleveland, to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, to handle the recruitment company's account, previously in-house. Billings were estimated to exceed $1 million.

title: Norton McNaughtonInc.(NRTY,NNM) reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 4
description: b-After an extraordinary charge, net of tax, of $ 401,000, or 6 cents a share. As a result of the repayment of long-term indebtedness, the company wrote off the remaining unamortized balance of deferred financing costs of $ 704,000. The latter was reflected in the consolidated statements of income as an extraordinary item.c-Net loss(Loss)Sales are net sales.

title: Bridge
description: Players often fail to realize that a minor-suit game in a 4-4 fit may be the right contract if three no-trump is unattractive and there is no major-suit fit. The diagramed example, noted and analyzed by the Rev. Caxton Doggett of Lake Junaluska, N.C., makes this point.

title: Times Square Club Announces Its Closing
description: Club USA, the $8 million nightclub-cum-playground that draws crowds of tourists and young New Yorkers each weekend, is to close next month, said its owner, Peter Gatien.

title: North Korea Says U.S. Pilot Admits a 'Flagrant Violation'
description: North Korea said today that a captured American helicopter pilot had confessed to illegally intruding into its territory and had asked for leniency so he can return to his family.

title: In Serbia and Croatia, Attacks on Independent Press Continue
description: Three weeks ago, the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, struck against a leading Zagreb newspaper, Vjesnik, by arranging for a friendly bank to buy it and dismiss its independent-minded editor.

title: Republican Bill Would Trim Aid for Poor Children Who Are Ill or Disabled
description: House Republicans are drafting legislation that would abolish Federal cash payments for 847,000 poor children who are severely disabled or chronically ill. They would replace the payments with vouchers that could be spent on a more limited program of medical care.

title: Beyond Probation: Trying to Break Cycle of Arrest and Rearrest
description: On a bone-chilling morning last April, Tony W., a powerfully built teen-ager who specialized in armed robberies on the streets of New York City, stepped out of one of New York State's most forbidding institutions for teen-agers to begin what he hoped would be a new life.

title: U.S. IS READYING FURTHER BILLIONS TO RESCUE MEXICO
description: The United States is preparing to spend billions of dollars, possibly as soon as next week, to help Mexico in its financial crisis. The money would be used to prop up the peso in foreign-exchange markets and help make payments on Mexico's national debt, an Administration official said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's that time of year when organizations, associations and publications of all sorts issue lists of those people they have deemed to be the "10 Best" or top of the heap in innumerable categories.

title: COMALCO CONSIDERS AN OFFERING OF U.S. ALUMINUM UNIT
description: Comalco Ltd., an Australian aluminum company, said yesterday that it was considering an initial public offering of stock in its United States subsidiary, the Commonwealth Aluminum Corporation. Commonwealth Aluminum, based in Lewisport, Ky., operates a scrap metal recycling plant and a rolling mill. Comalco said it had taken the first steps with the Securities and Exchange Commission to prepare a prospectus for the Commonwealth Aluminum offering. Comalco said the shares would be offered to investors in the United States "and certain other countries, but not in Australia or New Zealand." A decision is expected in February 1995. Comalco is controlled by the Australian mining and metals group CRA Ltd.

title: Sports of The Times; Starks Has Found An Answer
description: IN these dire times, with the Mighty Oak felled, the Knicks need leadership to steady their season. So John Starks took it upon himself to provide such guidance. Against the Nets Tuesday night at the Meadowlands, while Charles Oakley and his toe were nestled in a Manhattan hospital after surgery, Starks immediately took charge, or what he considered to be charge.

title: Time to Look at Baseball's Exemption
description: The owners of baseball's 28 major-league teams have declared an impasse in wage negotiations and imposed what their players dreaded most -- a cap on team payrolls. The players vow to continue their strike and seek legal remedies. The result is that baseball's wealthy owners and players have left the game in even sorrier shape than last year, when their failure to reach a new labor agreement destroyed the end of the regular season, the playoffs and the World Series.

title: Gun Exchange Plan Yields Few Results
description: The Goods for Guns exchange that took about 2,800 guns off the streets and out of homes in New York in a six-week period last year took in only 313 guns last week, the organization's founder said yesterday.

title: Loser for Maryland Governor Files Suit to Overturn Election
description: With three weeks until the scheduled inauguration of Parris N. Glendening as Maryland's next governor, the Republican he defeated, Ellen R. Sauerbrey, is doing what she can to keep him from being sworn in.

title: Miscellany
description: * Saturn Corp., Troy, Mich., has signed a 24-week sponsorship agreement with Hot Wired, the on-line computer service of Wired magazine. Beginning in mid-January, Hot Wired will carry Saturn advertising created by Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, including photographs of 1995 models and dealer locations.

title: Bassett Furniture Industries(BSET,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 510,000, or 4 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Armstrong Rules Lifted
description: The Federal Trade Commission has lifted pricing restrictions that were imposed on Armstrong World Industries Inc. 29 years ago. As part of a 1965 agreement to settle charges of unfair pricing practices by the company's predecessor, the Armstrong Cork Company, the commission prohibited Armstrong from negotiating agreements with wholesalers to set resale prices, and from discriminating in prices offered to wholesalers.

title: Gingrich PAC Adheres to Election Law; An Academic Course
description: To the Editor:

title: Shattered Nation: A special report.; Rwanda Now Faces Painful Ordeal of Rebirth
description: Signs that life is returning to normal can be found everywhere in Rwanda. A roaring crowd fills a Kigali stadium for a Sunday afternoon soccer match. The cement factory in the southwest is operating again. Children play in dirt schoolyards. Day laborers in their green aprons pick tea on vast estates. And the carols of worshipers pour forth in a packed church where scores were massacred in April.

title: Soprano Drops Out of the Met's 'Boccanegra'
description: Cheryl Studer, the soprano who was to sing Amelia in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra" next month, has withdrawn from the cast. Kiri Te Kanawa, who last sang the role at the Met in 1986, will take over Miss Studer's five performances, one of which is to be taped for television.

title: A Liberal Looks Back With Pride
description: AFTER more than two decades in government, Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, makes no apologies. He is what he is:

title: Honors
description: * The New York Festivals and the United Nations Department of Public Information, New York, named Marca Lintas, Bogota, Colombia, to receive the 1994 gold plaque U.N.D.P.I. Award for a television commercial promoting condom use to prevent the spread of AIDS. VVL/ BBDO, Brussels, was named to receive the silver plaque for a commercial against racial discrimination. The bronze plaque went to ALMAP/BBDO, Sao Paulo, Brazil, for an anti-AIDS spot. The awards will be presented Jan. 12 at a ceremony in New York.

title: Krone to Be Married
description: The annual Saratoga racing meet has always been good to jockey JULIE KRONE. This August, it will be really something special. Krone, 31, and MATT MUZIKAR, 25, plan to be married in August 1995 in Saratoga Springs.

title: Frito-Lay Puts Its Cowboy On 2 Horses at Same Time
description: After decades of playing cowboys in westerns from "Shane" to "City Slickers," Jack Palance is familiar with branding. Now the actor is becoming involved with one of the hottest trends in consumer marketing, co-branding.

title: Orange Has New Year's All to Itself (Well, Almost)
description: NBC's decision to televise the Orange Bowl on New Year's night should substantially lift the expected high ratings for the Nebraska-Miami game while aiding viewership for ABC's Sugar Bowl, the Orange Bowl's usual prime-time rival.

title: Declining Dollar Pushes Treasury Prices Lower
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday in thin trading, hurt by a sharp decline in the value of the dollar.

title: Young, Eager and Deep in Debt
description: Two weeks ago when Bill Clinton introduced his "Middle-Class Bill of Rights," it was no surprise that college tuition relief was first on the list. The steep cost of an education has become a problem for voters of all ages. The President's proposed $10,000 tax deduction for tuition is more generous than a Republican proposal that would increase the burden by making students newly responsible for interest accumulated while they were in school. But -- with a maximum saving of about $1,500 a year -- it still isn't going to solve anything.

title: State Approval Sought for Stricter Watershed Regulation
description: To protect its water supply, New York City has put together a plan to regulate everything from new development to the disposal of plowed snow in the vast upstate region that supplies the city's water.

title: Youth, Resisting Robbers, Is Slain on Subway Platform
description: Wanda Matthews always told her 17-year-old son Adonis to keep his jewelry hidden and not resist robbers. But just before midnight on Tuesday, on a subway platform in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, he was wearing a gold medallion and chain around his neck. And when two men tried to rob him, he fought back and was shot to death, the police said.

title: Walter McQuade, 72, Architecture Critic
description: Walter McQuade, a writer and architecture critic, died on Monday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. He was 72 and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: New Baby, New Books
description: THE Walt Disney Company makes creates movies, musicals and theme parks for children, of course, and is now also producing a book that tells parents how to raise them.

title: A Year to Forget: 1994 Leaves Mexico Reeling
description: There were clues right from the start that something was very, very wrong with Mexico's 1994.

title: The Last Ride of His Life
description: This beach needs lifeguards or a priest. The body of an expert surfer washed ashore here at Pillar Point last Friday, swallowed by waves that grow like weeds, and, yet, his peers are already leaping back in.

title: As Congress Fumes, Clinton Urges North Koreans to Free Pilot
description: President Clinton called on North Korea today to release an American pilot captured 11 days ago, as key lawmakers of both parties of Congress predicted that Congress would block a nuclear agreement between the two countries if the diplomatic crisis is not resolved.

title: New Jersey Ruling on Free Speech Burdens Shopping Malls
description: To the Editor:

title: Orange County Seeks Advice on Bond Sales
description: Orange County, Calif., is asking some of the nation's top brokerage firms to devise ways for it to sell bonds to help pay its debts in the wake of its bankruptcy filing.

title: For Apple, Clones and Competition
description: Apple Computer Inc. has picked its first Macintosh clone maker, a little-known company that may soon give Apple some tough competition.

title: Nets' Anderson Goes Absent Without Leave
description: On the day that Derrick Coleman finally returned to practice, Kenny Anderson felt the need to be absent.

title: Calendar: Shows And Tours
description: Antiques Show New York Coliseum, Broadway at West 59th Street; (212) 675-7036.

title: Test Device Appears to Aid Repair of Potentially Fatal Aneurysm
description: An experimental device that reinforces the body's main artery when it is weakened by an aneurysm can greatly simplify surgical repair of the condition, a new study being reported today shows.

title: Top Deal for Franco
description: JULIO FRANCO formally agreed yesterday to a $3.5 million, one-year contract with the Chiba Lotte Marines of Japan's Pacific League, the highest average annual value in the history of Japanese baseball.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: TOYS 'R' US SHARES FALL ON WEAK HOLIDAY SALES
description: Shares of Toys "R" Us Inc. fell 9 percent yesterday as analysts cut earnings estimates after the retailer reported lower-than-expected sales for the holiday season. Robert J. Schweich, an analyst with Wert heim Schroder & Company, said Toys "R" Us probably failed to achieve domestic sales growth of 4 percent in stores open more than a year. The retailer, based in Paramus, N.J., reported a 7.4 percent gain in such sales last year. In addition, Mr. Schweich said, profits in Europe might increase to $130 million to $140 million, compared with earlier projections of $150 million. Shares of Toys "R" Us fell $3, to $30.175, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Nelson to Return
description: Coach DON NELSON, who has missed the Warriors' last five games while recovering from viral pneumonia, is expected to return next Tuesday for a game at home against the San Antonio Spurs. Nelson, who last coached Golden State on Dec. 13, was hospitalized for four nights beginning Dec. 14. (AP)

title: Journal; Brock's Strange Journalism
description: Tabloid journalism is something you think you know when you see it, whether at the supermarket checkout or on the cash-for-trash television news magazines. But it can also be committed in footnoted articles in seemingly sober journals -- and can soil the national discourse about subjects far loftier than O. J.

title: Family of Dr. King, Feuding With U.S., May Curb Tours at Shrine
description: The tomb and birthplace of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the most popular tourist attraction in Atlanta, may be visible only from a distance if a long-running feud between the National Park Service and the King family is not resolved.

title: Essay; Office Pool, 1995
description: What fools we mortal chin-pullers be, to presume to predict tomorrow's news in the knowledge that multitudes will keep track and later go nyah-nyah. But there is profit in prophecy if we use this oracular exercise to hone our humility and stretch our imaginations.

title: Chechnya Sounds Alarm of a Russian Breakup
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico: Don't Panic Over the Peso
description: Mexico's peso crisis has obviously shaken Mexican officials and foreign investors alike and could damage Mexico's short-term economic prospects. But it does not reflect fundamental flaws in Mexico's newly liberalized economy. Moreover, President Ernesto Zedillo's economic ministers have responded to the challenge competently, avoiding premature efforts to peg a new exchange rate. The markets will eventually stabilize. Yesterday the peso rebounded some 15 percent.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Getting Things Squared Away? Professional Help Is Plentiful
description: FOR those who make New Year's resolutions, organizing finances, housecleaning and rearranging a home office are right up at the top of the list with losing 10 pounds.

title: Market Place; A patent issue in GATT clouds the outlook for Glaxo Holdings.
description: GLAXO HOLDINGS P.L.C. says a little-noted patent measure tucked into the new world trade agreement may benefit the company, but after reading the fine print, analysts are not so sure.

title: Gingrich PAC Adheres to Election Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Wherever Parcells Travels, There Are Giants in the Mist
description: It seems as though every time he looks at an opponent, Bill Parcells sees some remnant of his past as the Giants' coach. A few weeks ago, it was Dolphins receiver Mark Ingram. Last week, it was Bears running back, Lewis Tillman.

title: Computer Replaces Razor For Rabbi's Prison Picture
description: A conflict between a New York State prison regulation requiring that inmates be photographed clean-shaven and a religious belief that a man's beard must not be touched was resolved in Federal court yesterday through the latest computer technology.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOISE CASCADE CORP., Boise, Idaho, a maker of paper and office products, has acquired OE&S Business Products, Jacksonville, Fla., an office products distributor. Terms were not disclosed. NATIONAL CITY BANCSHARES INC., Evansville, Ind., a bank holding company, said it planned to buy United Financial Bancorp Inc. in a stock swap valued at $20.8 million.

title: When Hope Falters, Balm for the Soul
description: WHEN the ancients were sick, they walked among trees and plants and breathed the fresh air to soothe their pain.

title: Survival Assured, A Designer Can Plan
description: As a textile designer, Leonard F. traveled the world, working in Haiti, Hong Kong and Italy in a career that spanned nearly 30 years.

title:
HORSE RACING;
The Jockeys and the Tracks Are Still on Separate Paths
description: Jockeys' Guild members and officials from the nation's race tracks met separately today as their dispute over accident insurance for the riders moved toward a showdown.

title: Petrie Stores
description: Shares of Petrie Stores of Secaucus, N.J., established a 52-week low of $21.625 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange before rebounding slightly. Analysts are worried about the earnings of Petrie and other retailers after a disappointing Christmas season.

title: DIRECTOR OF C.I.A. TO LEAVE, ENDING TROUBLED TENURE
description: The Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey Jr., has resigned after a troubled tenure of just under two years as the nation's chief of spies.

title: Battle Over Black Studies; City College Uses Classes to Counter Jeffries
description: The black studies department at City College still offers more than 30 courses each semester, much as it did before its chairman, Prof. Leonard Jeffries, drew national attention in 1991 for a speech that vilified Jews.

title: Region News Briefs; Woman Hit in Head By Metro-North Train
description: A woman was critically injured Tuesday night when she leaned over a railroad station platform in Mount Vernon and was struck in the head by a Metro-North Commuter Railroad train.

title: Spy Agency Under Siege; C.I.A. Critics Calling For Radical Changes
description: With his resignation as Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey leaves an agency under siege and still trying to articulate a new mission for the post-cold-war era.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing Census Bureau estimates of state population gains and losses over the last decade misstated the 1994 population of Texas. It was 18,378,000, not 19,378,000.

title: Grades Force Center To End Clemson Career
description: The senior center DEVIN GRAY has been ruled academically ineligible for the second semester, ending his Clemson career, Coach RICK BARNES said yesterday.

title: Knicks Get Another Victory but Have a Loss Too
description: The Knicks won another game, but they lost another player to injury.

title: Accepting 'Soft Money' As a Necessary Evil
description: The Mercer County Democratic Committee had only one local election on its hands this year, a low-key county freeholder race in which the Democrats were trounced. So why were Jeffrey Katzenberg of Hollywood and the Walt Disney Company, and Leon Hess of the giant oil company that bears his name, and the teamsters' union in Washington pouring tens of thousands of dollars into the county party's coffers?

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF PCS HEALTH SYSTEMS TO RETIRE
description: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that the chief executive of its PCS Health Systems Inc. unit would retire.
